story: The reporter dismantled plans to create a Brexit commemorative coin, which is something Chancellor Philip Hammond had put forward during the 2018&nbspBudget on Monday.Mr Crisp insisted Leave voters would not be bought off with the proposed 50p coin and will continue to demand the change they asked for when opting to exit the European Union.The  Brussels correspondent told Raw Politics: This has to go down as one of the most pathetic things I have ever seen. One, to put out a coin or two, out of this flailing and tired Government.There is actually a serious point that I want to make about this. This idea the people who voted for Brexit can be bought off with a coin, blue passport or a festival of Brexit. This is the kind of thing which stores up precisely the kind of resentment or anger towards politicians.                Even Remainer Peer RIDICULES desperate calls for second Brexit vote                 Australia top diplomat urges UK - 'SEIZE Brexit to enjoy these perks!'People didn&rsquot vote Brexit for these things, they voted because they want change.Mr Crisp added: I would say that only a Government minister would think that anyone who collects coins is in any way normal, or should have any attention paid to them at all.The proposed coin is set to become available on Brexit day, March 29 at 11pm. The coin is expected to carry the words &ldquoFriendship With All Nations.Chancellor Hammond unveiled his plan as part of the 2018 Budget alongside other key economic measures the British Government will pursue for the coming year.&nbspBrexit news: Crisp branded as pathetic plans to issue a 50p commemorative coin (Image: EURONEWS&bullPARLIAMENT TV)He vowed the Budget would herald a &ldquobrighter future following years of austerity imposed in the wake of the 2007-2008 credit crunch.Mr&nbspHammond said an extra &pound1billion will be made available to the MoD to increase the UK&rsquos cyber and submarine capabilities while an additional &pound160million has been earmarked to protect counter-terror police numbers.However&nbspthe Chancellor&rsquos overarching message was that eight years of cuts to public services are now coming to an end &ndash but only if the UK secures a Brexit deal.He announced an additional &pound500 million has been earmarked for no-deal Brexit contingency preparations, hinting an emergency Budget could take place in the Spring if a withdrawal agreement with Brussels is not reached.                May holds talks with 120 business leaders to CALM no-deal Brexit fearsBut arch-federalist MEP Guy Verhofstadt on Wednesday claimed Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab torpedoed a Brexit deal during a tense meeting with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier.In minutes from the European Parliament&rsquos Conference of Presidents meeting, Mr Verhofstadt confirms &ldquothere had been hope for an agreement based on a global proposal on a withdrawal agreement.But during his last Brussels meeting, Mr Raab &ldquoinformed Mr Barnier that that proposal would not be backed by the UK Government, which had made the conclusion of an agreement at the forthcoming European Council meeting impossible.At the summit, which was just three days later, European leaders decided &ldquodecisive progress had not been made and they shelved plans for an emergency November summit.The Brexit Secretary appeared to suggest a deal with Brussels would be reached by November 21 but his department quickly dismissed the claim, saying there is &ldquono set date for the end of the negotiations.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer tweeted: This must be one of the quickest u-turns in political history. ??@DominicRaab? told MPs that a Brexit deal would be done by the end of November. Three hours later his own department was forced to correct the record. What a mess.

story: Brexit news: Labour's Sir Keir Starmer accused Mr Raab of pulling a 'messy U-turn' (Image:  IMAGES)In a letter to MPs, Mr Raab said &ldquothe end is now firmly in sight for the exit talks, which have hit another impasse in recent weeks over the Irish border issue.The note included a pledge to provide an update to the House of Commons Exiting the EU Committee &ldquowhen a deal is finished - and gave November 21 as a &ldquosuitable date for him to appear before the panel.The letter sparked a flurry of speculation that a breakthrough in the stalled talks could be on the horizon.But after it became public today, Mr Raab&rsquos Department for Exiting the European Union (DExEU) was quick to play down hopes an agreement was imminent.Instead, the department insisted the November 21 reference was simply in response to a date suggested by the select committee for the Brexit Secretary to give evidence.It added: There is no set date for the negotiations to conclude.                The major hurdles left to clear with just FIVE MONTHS until Brexit day                May holds talks with 120 business leaders to CALM no-deal Brexit fearsLabour seized on the confusion by accusing Mr Raab of a &ldquomessy U-turn.Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer tweeted: &ldquoThis must be one of the quickest u-turns in political history. @DominicRaab told MPs that a Brexit deal would be done by the end of November.Three hours later his own department was forced to correct the record. What a mess.The letter from Mr Raab was penned on October 24 but only made public by the Commons committee today.In it, the Brexit Secretary focussed on the last remaining issue in the way of an exit deal - a solution to the Irish border conundrum.Mr Raab's letter suggested a Brexit deal would be concluded by November 21 (Image:  IMAGES)                Reporter tears into 'PATHETIC' Government's 50p Brexit coinBoth the UK and EU have agreed on the need for a &lsquobackstop&rsquo contingency to prevent a &lsquohard&rsquo frontier, with no new border posts or customs checks,between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic after the split but neither side is willing to budge on its demands on how to achieve it.Theresa May&rsquos proposals would see the entire UK temporarily remain in the bloc&rsquos customs union until a permanent solution can be implemented.But Brussels is insisting on measures which would see just Northern Ireland stay part of the customs union - something the Prime Minister has refused to accept.In his latest letter, the Brexit Secretary acknowledged the difficulty of reaching a solution over the Irish border backstop but said he was confident a deal would be done.Sir Keir chided Mr Raab for his 'U-turn' in a tweet (Image:  IMAGES)                EU must beg Britain back into a NEW EU warns ex-French leader Sarkozy                Tory peer TEARS into Barnier during heated Brexit debateHe wrote: Despite our differences, we are not far from an agreement on this issue. We agree on the principle of a UK-wide customs backstop. An agreement on the details of that backstop should be possible.Both sides agree that this backstop cannot provide for a permanent UKEU relationship and are committed to a future relationship that works for the whole of the UK, including Northern Ireland.We are open to talking about ways to achieve this and committed to continuing discussions in order to reach an agreement.The end is now firmly in sight and, while obstacles remain, it cannot be beyond us to navigate them. We have resolved most of the issues and we are building up together what the future relationship should look like and making real progress.We now need to acknowledge the progress that has been made and now work rapidly through the remaining issues and come to an agreement that works for both sides.The Irish border question remains the main stumbling block to sealing a Brexit deal (Image:  IMAGES)Mr Raab was due to appear before the House of Commons Exiting the EU Committee on October 24, but he pulled out ahead of the European Council summit on October 17-18.DExEU later said he was only committed to appear once a deal had been finalised.Responding to Mr Raab to accept his November 21 date, committee chair Hilary Benn said he was disappointed with the new Brexit Secretary's failure to follow the pattern of regular updates established by his predecessor David Davis.And he rejected Mr Raab&rsquos proposal to keep the panel updated by letter as &ldquonot sufficient or effective.Labour MP Mr Benn added: Having been a member of this committee, you will know that this is not how committees undertake inquiries and is not conducive to scrutiny.

title: GCHQ latest instagram intelligence agency uk intelligence agency
story: GCHQ published this picture as its first Instagram post  (Image: INSTAGRAM )GCHQ&rsquos first post, uploaded on Wednesday October 31, was a picture of the headquarters behind a bar with the caption: &ldquoWell this is going to be interesting. Follow us for a glimpse into our secret world!The picture of behind the gates of the headquarters ironically had a &rsquono photography&rsquo sign.The agency is the intelligence and security organisation responsible for providing signal intelligence and information to the government and army of the UK.A GHCQ spokeswoman said the public account was designed to show how the Cheltenham-based agency was &ldquoworking 247 to help keep the country safe.                GCHQ codebreakers reveal latest top recruit: Bletchley the Guide DogShe said: &ldquoHopefully this will help dispel some myths and show who we are as iniduals.&ldquoAs we enter our centenary year, we&rsquore more keen than ever that people get a picture of what life is really like as a GCHQ employee.&ldquoWe hope our Instagram channel will encourage talented people to consider working with us at GCHQ to help keep the country safe.&ldquoYou&rsquoll not only learn about our work to stay one step ahead of those wishing to do us harm, but also get a glimpse at our hobbies, clubs and coffee shops.The main base of GCHQ is in Cheltenham  (Image: )&ldquoFrom the Cotswolds to Cornwall, from London to Lincolnshire and the wonderful dry stone walls of North Yorkshire, this will be a chance to show off some of the iconic locations we're proud to call home.And of course there's bound to be puzzles and maybe some surprises too .Its headquarters of GCHQ, which are dubbed &lsquothe doughnut&rsquo, are located in the suburbs of Cheltenham.The intelligence organisation is tasked, along with M15 and M16, with managing the cyber threat posed by nation states and criminals, preventing terror attacks and keep children safe online.GCHQ wants to make the organisation more transparent with its social media accounts  (Image: )The spy agency joined Twitter two years ago, also in a bid to become more transparent.It has tweeted more than 2,000 times and now has a following of 75,000.The agency has used the account to share the appeals it supports, for example information about the heads of the intelligence agencies working together to show their support for World Mental Health Day.There are now a huge one billion people using Instagram who will be able to get a snapshot of top secret life at GCHQ.The handle for the Instagram account is @GCHQ

title: BBC Weather news London forecast Met Office hurricane Oscar weekend November storm
story: BBC Weather forecaster Mel Coles warned wind speeds will pick up to as high as 65 miles per hour for northeastern parts of Britain on Friday evening and into the weekend.The BBC Weather forecaster warned that despite temperatures picking up on Wednesday and Thursday, the weather will take a turn for the worst on Friday.The BBC host said: &ldquoTemperatures not doing too badly through Thursday that rain gradually clears away as we head towards Thursday night and into Friday.&ldquoClear skies &ndash that means temperatures will fall away and another frosty night and then maybe some mist and fog around first thing.                BBC Weather: Britons WARNED of GALES this weekend as Storm Oscar hits                ITV Good Morning Britain: Laura Tobin terrified by guest live on air&ldquoBut actually with a ridge of high pressure, things will be fairly settled for many areas of the UK on Friday.&ldquoSome spells of crisp autumn sunshine around.But the BBC host warned there will be a u-turn in weather conditions on Friday, she said: &ldquoBut things start to turn a little bit downhill as we head towards the latter stages of Friday and that is courtesy of ex-hurricane Oscar.&ldquoIt has been working its way across the Atlantic and that will bring wet and windy conditions into the far&nbspnorth west&nbspof Scotland where we could have gusts of around 65 miles an hour.BBC Weather: Forecaster warns of 65 mph in UK on Friday night (Image: BBC)&ldquoBut with that south westerly flow temperatures will be back into the mid-teens &ndash so noticeably milder but windy on Saturday.The Met Office also warned that despite narrowly avoiding a direct hit on the nation, the remnants of Hurricane Oscar will still cause strong winds for northeastern parts of the country.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: &ldquoAt some point on Thursday and Friday the hurricane will transition into what we call an extratropical depression.&ldquoIn other words, a typical area of low pressure with weather fronts, wind and rain and so on.&ldquoThen it is likely to head to the north-west of the UK during the weekend.&ldquoNow, a few days ago some of the computers models were predicting a more direct hit for the UK. Thankfully, it is now moving to the north and it looks most likely that it will be the far northwest that experiences the strongest winds.Mr McGivern warned the ex-hurricane could get caught in the jet stream, which could fuel its energy.BBC Weather: Storm to avoid direct hit on UK (Image: CBS news&bullNHC)He said: &ldquoWhat happens when hurricanes move north. They leave warm waters behind so they lose that energy source. But often they can get swept up into the jet stream and that provides another fuel source for these ex-hurricanes and by later Thursday.The Met Office forecaster added: &ldquoBy the end of Friday the winds will be picking up. So Friday is actually a cold, frosty and sunny start for many places.&ldquoA fine day for most of us but we will notice the winds picking up and the cloud building and then on Saturday there is ex-Oscar to the northeast of Britain bringing strong winds to northwestern parts of the country and bringing outbreaks of rain to northern areas.

story: As the spooky Halloween celebrations get underway for the creepiest day on the calendar, paranormal researcher and demonologist Tony Spera has explained why he thinks religion could be behind the paranormal.Halloween marks the night of All Hallow&rsquos Evening, or All Hallow&rsquos Eve, a period of mourning for the dead, saints and Christian martyrs.Speaking on Fox News, Mr Spera said: &ldquoMy faith, first of all, makes me believe it because God is a supernatural being. And if you believe in God, which I do, then you would need to believe that he created us in his image, which is a supernatural being, a spirit.When asked what a ghost or a demon would look like, Mr Spera said there is both a body and a spirit                Halloween 2018: Are vampires and witches REAL? Are there witch covens?                Halloween WARNING: BEWARE of 'lurking' satanic evil spirits TONIGHTHe said: &ldquoIf you die your body will wither away but you, as a spirit, will continue on.The paranormal researcher said the spirit will go towards &ldquothe light, adding: &ldquoIn other words, everybody is offered the light and it is up to you if you decide you are going to that light.&ldquoIf you are a good person you are going to be offered the light and that light leads you to God and to heaven.Mr Spera insisted you would remain &ldquoearthbound if you reject the light.The paranormal researcher said the spirit could also have the capability to scare people.Halloween 2018: Paranormal researcher says spirits can remain earthbound (Image: &bullFox News)He added: &ldquoThere are people who maybe were tragically killed or murdered instantaneously, for instance, 911 where the planes went into the building, instantly gone.&ldquoYou&rsquore not even aware that they are dead. And they are in a confused state and they roam the earth looking for their house, looking for their relatives or whatever.The spirit of Halloween is likely to have people around the world dishing out horror stories or tuning into their favourite horror films.But a Russian MP has said the Pagan holiday instead draws children closer to &ldquoSatan and suicide as children across the globe preparing to don spooky outfits for the event.Controversial pro-Christian MP, Vitaly Milonov, urged Russia&rsquos s Education Minister, Olga Vasilyeva, to ban the &ldquopagan Satan-worshipping holiday in schools to save them from Hell.In an address to Russian parliament, Mr Milonov said he had received countless complaints from parents who were concerned that their children were set to take part in Halloween celebrations.Mr Milonov said: &ldquoMany schoolchildren are being persuaded to participate in this shady holiday.&ldquoThey are being forced to make costumes of imps, decorate classrooms with otherworldly attributes and prepare thematic plays.&ldquoThis holiday has pagan, anti-Christian roots. It well known that it&rsquos based on worshiping dark forces and Satan as well as glorifying the grim Celtic cult of death.He added that Halloween can &ldquodraw children to mysticism, Satanism and suicide.Mr Milonov asked Ms Vasilyeva to &ldquotake all possible measures to prevent Halloween celebrations at schools and added that if the rules are broken there should be &ldquothe toughest disciplinary measures to be implemented against those officials, who indulge the insight of mystical Satanism into the minds of our children.Halloween celebrations are rooted in the Gaelic start of winter, known as Samhai.Samhain is an ancient Gaelic festival marking the start of winter and the end of the harvest seasons.The holiday is traditionally observed from October 31 to November 1 &ndash the midway point between the Autumn Equinox and the Winter Solstice.READ YOUR HALLOWEEN HOROSCOPE HERE

story: Elon Musk has just announced a major new update for the Tesla Autopilot&rsquos Summon feature (Image: Getty)Tesla&rsquos Autopilot is a form of advanced cruise control that can handle some driving tasks but requires the driver to be able to retake control at any minute.However, the Summon feature can be activated without anyone in the car and enables the owner to remotely move the vehicle a few feet in car parks.It is mainly used to pull the cars out of the garage, as the owner still needs to be within viewing distance and be able to stop the vehicle if needed.Tesla&rsquos CEO, Elon Musk, has just promised a major update, which will see Summon taking advantage of its camera agnostic computer vision system.                Tesla is now selling a cheaper 260-mile Model 3 - Here&rsquos how much i...                Tesla shares ROCKET as Citron Research CHANGES mind on car companyReplying to a Tesla user, who posted a video of his car using Summon, Mr Musk said: &ldquoFor those unfamiliar, this uses Tesla AutoparkSummon.&ldquoSlightly smarter version hopefully ready soon.&ldquoBy next year, a Tesla should be able to drive around a parking lot, find an empty spot, read signs to confirm it&rsquos valid and park.People have responded with excitement to the update on Twitter.Tesla&rsquos Autopilot is a form of advanced cruise control that can handle some driving tasks (Image: Getty)One user said: What a great idea.The superchargers by me are very organised.Would love for the car to automate this process.Another added: So a batmobile?By next year, a Tesla should be able to drive around a car park (Image: Getty)Mr Musk has been entangled in a series of well-publicised scandals  (Image: Getty)You are making batmobiles.That's wicked.The news comes a week after the American company announced surprisingly high profits in this financial quarter despite Mr Musk&rsquos several high-profile scandals - from bizarre Twitter spats to lawsuits.The last three months have been a rollercoaster ride for the electric car company, whose boss Mr Musk spiralled out of control and has faced a litany of legal woes.Tesla posted a profit of $312million (&pound242million) in the last three months - beating analysts&rsquo gloomy predictions, as the mid-priced Tesla model 3 was the fifth best-selling passenger car in America, according to industry analyst Edmunds.Over the same period, Mr Musk has been entangled in a series of well-publicised scandals which seem not to have affected his flagship company&rsquos bottom line.

story: These spooky headlines all sound like they could be taken from the plot of a horror film, but in fact they’re just some of the scariest horror stories to have taken place in Britain.Here, Sun Online takes a look the UK horror stories that are scarier than fiction.In , a man named Bill Ramsey, , took himself to Southend Police Station and asked to be locked up for his and the public’s safety, claiming he was a savage werewolf.The officers on duty were reluctant to put him in the cells after seeing he had no criminal history.But it was at this point that Bill turned, growling and snarling at Duty Sergeant Terry Fisher before grabbing the ft tall,  stone police officer by the throat and throwing him across the station’s car park.Chaos ensued and a total of eight police officers were required to restrain the werewolf man, who was fighting them on all fours.That wasn’t the end of the ordeal though.Bill then used his strength to smash his way through a re-enforced hatch in his cell’s door, managing to get both his arm and head stuck in the opening before he was sedated with a dose nearly three times the amount of an average person.PC Tony Belford said that he’d never seen anything like it before or since - and the news even made The Sun’s front page – earning Bill the nickname of ‘The Southend Werewolf’.On  February , Cannock Chase murderer Raymond Leslie Morris was sentenced to le imprisonment for the rape and murder of seven-year-old Christine Darby.Its widely thought the corpses of Margaret Reynolds, , and Diana Joy Tt, , both found in January  were also linked to the predator.All three bodies were found within a mile of each other in the Staffordshire woodland.And in the very the same area, there have been numerous sightings of the black-eyed ghost of a young girl, leading many to suspect that it might be the spirit of one of Morris’ victims.The first report was in the summer of  when a young woman heard a child frantically shouting for help in Cannock Chase forest.On locating the sound, the woman found a little girl of around six years old on a dirt track.She had completely black eyes with no trace of white, and quickly disappeared into the woodland.More than  years later, another woman had a very similar experience in the haunted forest. “We instantly started running towards the noise,” the eyewitness told the Sunday Mercury.“We couldn’t find the child anywhere and so stopped to catch our breath.”On turning around, she saw a girl of no more than  years old with her hands over her eyes.“She put her arms down by her side and opened her eyes. That’s when I saw they were completely black, no iris, no white, nothing. I jumped back and grabbed my daughter. When I looked again, the child was gone. It was so strange.”Various paranormal experts have since investigated the area, with the YouTube channel Haunted Finders even managing to capture the ghost on camera in .Cemeteries are creepy places. But in the late s and early s there was an added spookiness to the decaying and decrepit Highgate Cemetery in North London, after numerous people reported sightings of a supernatural being.One was made by British Psychic and Occult Society member David Farrant, who wrote a letter to the Hampstead and Highgate Express claiming that he had seen “a grey figure” in the cemetery Christmas Eve .A handful of people claimed that they had also seen a tall, dark figure, floating behind the railings.These reports caught the interest of another local man Sean Manchester – a real-le vampire hunter – who believed that the ghostly figure was that of a Romanian ‘Vampire of the Undead’ that had been brought to England in the early s.Finally, after  years of hunting, Manchester published a book in which he claimed to have successfully staked, beheaded and burnt the vampire.But with no photo evidence, some believe the vampire could still be out there.While the ghost of the young girl in Cannock Chase ran away from people, there have been reports of ghosts who have attacked people in the UK, too.Greyfriars Cemetery in Edinburgh, Scotland, is home to a number of notable names, including Thomas Riddell – the inspiration Voldemort in JK Rowling’s Harry Potter books.But the cemetery is also home to one resident even more chilling than the Dark Lord himself.Sir George ‘Bluid’ MacKenzie was a th century lawyer who is blamed for the deaths of thousands of men during Charles II’s religious persecution of Presbyterians in Scotland - and his ghost still haunts the area to this day.MacKenzie laid undisturbed for more than  years before his spirit was reportedly first encountered in .A homeless man decided to take shelter in MacKenzie’s final resting place – the Black Mausoleum – on a dark and stormy night when something terrying happened.An ancient coffin allegedly collapsed beneath him, plunging him into a pit containing still decomposing plague victims, and the man ran from the scene covered in dust, startling a passerby that was out walking their dog.It is believed that the incident disturbed the spirit of MacKenzie,  and since then there have been more than  recorded incidents of poltergeist attacks on members of the public there.Volunteer guide Willie Telford told Edinburgh Evening News: “People have been bitten, scratched, kicked, pushed, they get burn marks, they feel sick, they feel cold.And it gets worse.Borley Rectory in Essex is widely regarded as ‘the most haunted house in England’.There have been reports of strange incidents at the Victorian house for decades, including sightings of a ghost nun and a phantom coach driven by two headless horsemen.But things really escalated in , when the resident Reverend Guy Eric Smith contacted a national newspaper to report otherworldly activity, including bells ringing and the sound of footsteps.The paper sent paranormal investigator Harry Price to carry out research, and the activity intensied, with reports including the throwing of vases and stones.The Smiths soon left the property, with the reverend’s we believing that Price had been behind it all. But the strange occurrences continued.Smith’s replacement, Reverend Lionel Algernon Foyster, also recorded incidents including bell-ringing, writing appearing on the wall and even his we, Marianne, being thrown from her bed by a poltergeist.The mystery remained unsolved and the house burnt down in  before being completely demolished five years later.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond theresea may budget
story: I know for many, the past few years haven’t been easy. But I’m happy to tell Sun on Sunday readers that their hard work is paying off.Our jobs market has defied many of the naysayers.Near record numbers of people have a job and unemployment has fallen in every region across the country.There are more than .million additional people in work since .While this is a huge achievement, sometimes it’s easy to forget that behind these numbers are thousands of people up and down our country who are now better able to provide for their families.They can get up every morning knowing they have the security that only a job can bring.And what’s more, they are being rewarded with a pay rise — this month’s figures show the strongest wage growth in almost a decade.Contrary to myths peddled by the opposition, it’s people at the bottom of the pay scale who have benefited most.The lowest earners working full-time have seen the fastest rise in pay thanks to our National Living Wage and the proportion of low-paid jobs is at a record low.Tomorrow I will deliver my Budget, where I will show how our careful focus on fixing the economy is bearing fruit.Thanks to the balanced approach we have taken — getting our debt falling, while keeping taxes low — and the hard work of the people of the UK, I will be able to set out how we will be investing in our future.Much of the talk surrounding Budgets is often technical. Many, many experts and commentators will have their own take on how the economy is doing.While this is, of course, important, what most ordinary people really care about is how the Budget will improve their day-to-day lives.And one of the issues which I know Sun on Sunday readers care a lot about is transport. With a thousand more people moving into work every day, it’s important that we help to get them there on time.Many of you preparing to start the working week tomorrow will know the frustration of having your journey to work ruined by delays caused by poorly maintained roads. Or of having your car or van damaged by potholes.This isn’t just a bad way to start the day, it’s bad for businesses large and small, and it can be really damaging to the wider economy as well.It’s estimated that congestion costs UK households more than £billion every year. That’s why tomorrow I will announce a bumper £billion investment in our country’s transport network — including a new £.billion fund ring-fencing vehicle excise duty raised in England for spending on our roads.As a former Transport Secretary, I know that these are the arteries that keep our country alive – and they need taking care of. Thirty-two years ago tomorrow, Margaret Thatcher officially opened the final stretch of the M.While few would claim to love this motorway, it’s easy to forget what a landmark moment this was for our country’s transport infrastructure. Three decades later, I am committed to honouring that legacy.And as important as our major roads are, smaller local roads are just as vital to our everyday lives.That’s why I will also announce tomorrow £million of immediate cash for councils to maintain and improve local roads — fixing potholes, repairing damaged roads and keeping bridges safe and open.A further £million on top of that will help improve local junctions, allowing better access to workplaces, high streets and other community facilities.This is also part of our commitment to bridging the gap between our regions. Those in rural parts of the country should have the same chances to get on in le and not have poor transport connections limiting their potential.The funding will help make journeys quicker and easier, while boosting productivity and improving access.And because I know that not everyone drives, I will also invest in local transport projects which could include new bus, tram and cycling routes.And I will also look to the future by investing in next-generation methods of transport, which could potentially include self-driving shuttle services.Not only could this revolutionise our transport network, it will also help us become a global leader developing future technologies.And finally, as I earlier announced with the Prime Minister, I am happy to confirm we will also be freezing fuel duty, for the ninth year in a row.This will keep the cost of fuel down for millions of drivers across the UK — saving people around £million this year alone.These measures are only possible due to our careful management of the economy over the past few years — and the hard work of the British people.This country has a bright future ahead, and — thanks to this vital investment package — the journey there just got a bit smoother.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: In a victory for The Sun, Philip Hammond will today announce a commemorative Brexit p coin, available from March , , to mark the moment we leave the EU.It will have the Queen’s head on one side and the phrase “Friendship with all nations” on the other — exactly the type of positive, outward-looking message we want to send.Despite the Remain naysayers’ claims, Britain remains a top global financial, diplomatic and military power.Unshackled from the EU, we will boom as a global business hub by developing new relationships.Despite the Government’s commemorative move, the Royal Mail refuses to release a Brexit stamp, claiming our exit will not be “an important anniversary”. What a load of codswallop!They thought it was appropriate to issue stamps commemorating TV show Game Of Thrones and for when we joined the EEC in  and the Single Market in  . . .Royal Mail bosses clearly detest the democratic decision to leave the EU.But for them to pretend Brexit is not a genuinely signicant historical moment is first-class buffoonery.IT has been a sad weekend in football.Immensely popular Leicester City owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha died alongside four others in a helicopter crash on Saturday night.The Thai billionaire bankrolled their  title-winning season, one of the beautul game’s greatest fairytales.The immense outpouring of grief from Foxes supporters showed how loved he was, while fans from teams as far afield as Inter Milan paid their respects alongside them on what is being described as the “darkest day” in Leicester’s history.RIP, Vichai.Meanwhile, former England star and ex-gaffer Glenn Hoddle is recovering in hospital after collapsing on TV.The reaction of footie fans and stars he played alongside, against and managed shows how well regarded he is.Get well soon, Glenn.THE proposed reform of non-disclosure agreementsis welcome.These contracts serve a purpose in some fields, such as business, where confidentiality is often necessary.But after the “Sir” Philip Green scandal last week, it is clear to all that they are being grossly misused.NDAs were not created so that the rich and powerful could gag people who make serious accusations against them.In a free society, people must always be able to blow the whistle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: latest telethon shows us once and for all that c4s just a load of cake and balls
story: You watch BBC’s Children In Need, you’re getting Clare Balding, Doctor Who and dancers, whether you like it or not.ITV  It’d take sniper fire or a dinner setting next to Sir Phillip Green before Cowell was a no-show.Channel , though Apart from a bit of a secondhand cake-baking and Gogglebox, I was drawing a blank before Friday night.So it was with a mix of fascination and dread that I tuned into Stand Up To Cancer. A seven-hour slog live from Westminster City Hall, presented by Adam Hills, Maya Jama and the network’s spare part Alan Carr, who set the tone for most of what followed interviewing Foxy from SAS: Who Dares Wins.“It’s been announced you’ve got a new Stand Up To Cancer series starting next year. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. I know you’ve been fingering my Garibaldis.”See. I did warn you.This week’s winner is camp Frank, from The Apprentice, and US outlaw Jesse James.Sent in by Peter Budgen, via email. Picture research Alfie Snelling.This Morning, Rylan Clark-Neal: “Listen, you’re Martine McCutcheon, you’re a living legend.”Strictly, Tess Daly to Doctor Who’s Mandip Gill: “Congratulations on a brilliant series. It’s fantastic, isn’t it ” No.And X Factor, Ayda Field to Scarlett Lee: “You could sing the shopping list and I’d enjoy it.”Then you haven’t seen theof her shopping list.David Haye introducing himself to the winning Apprentice team as “the Hayemaker himself”.Channel  News managing to have a studio discussion about Press injunctions without anyone from the Press.The X Factor pretending Brendan Murray is “a plumber” rather than a professional musician managed by Louis Walsh.Dr Who’s latest right-on brain fart being Donald Trump and grime-loving spiders.And the BBC hiding The Mash Report behind a smokescreen of “satire” when everyone can see it’s simply spouting Auntie’s prejudices against the Tories, Brexit and working-class people.Just in case you weren’t already reminded of them on an almost hourly basis.Will there ever be a charity telethon without the deadening presence of John Bishop How come X Factor drag-act Thomas Pound’s alter-ego wasn’t Thomas Poundland Why did hardly anyone swear in Press  And where the hell did EastEnders’ prisoners all get their amazing suntans They look like they’ve just come off a fortnight’s golf in the Algarve, not a le stretch.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which Elizabethan playwrite wrote A Midsummer Night’s Dream ”Stuart: “Pass.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Kenneth Clark presented which landmark TV series on the history of art ”Andy: “The Antiques Roadshow.”Ben Shephard: “In which Latin American country is the ancient Mayan temple El Castillo ”Sue: “Egypt.”And Ben Shephard: “Northampton is the county town of which English county ”Kirsty: “Pass.”Jose Mourinho: “If Ronaldo has two touches, he can score a hat-trick.”Phil Thompson: “Elyounoussi is a flash in the pan all the time.”Steve McManaman: “United got a goal back with  minutes left and now it’s -, there’s even more time left.”Compiled by Graham WrayOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. title: ghost hunting apps
story: These are just some of the paranormal phenomena experienced by ghost hunters ft below ground in one of Londons abandoned tube stations.Spectrum Paranormal, a London-based group made up of Hazel F Williams and her nephew Dean, often conducts investigations in South Kentish Town tube station - a building with a spooky history.Originally called Castle Road, the station opened in , but was closed in  due to too few people using it. It has since been nicknamed the ghost tube station.In the s it was rumoured that a commuter, Mr Brackett, met a grisly end there, after becoming trapped when the train stopped and he got off by mistake.No more tubes came and it was locked up, but he couldnt walk on the tracks, says Hazel. Legend has it that he died in there, and his ghost still haunts the station today as he looks for a way out.Spectrum have been conducting investigations since , going into peoples haunted homes to help them with supernatural activity and running public ghost hunting events.Weve done a lot of investigations down here, says Hazel. Weve heard mysterious footsteps, knocking and banging.One day we even made contact with the spirit of a nine-year-old girl who spoke to us, I think she may have died in an accident when the tube station was still in use.While the pro hunters naturally have state of the art equipment, there are plenty of ghost hunting apps available for mobiles.Sun Online went underground with Spectrum for a special Halloween ghost hunt, pitting three iPhone apps against their specialist toolkit.And things certainly got spooky...Could Mr Brackett still be haunting the station today  Thats what Hazel, Dean and Sun Online are hoping to find out with our technology.During previous visits to the station, they have heard what they describe as poltergeist activity, including banging and footsteps, assomebody is trying to find their way out.Theyve also had positive responses when trying out ouija boards in the station.Weve called out his name in the past and got a few replies, him moving the board or knocking says Hazel.The building does have an extremely creepy atmosphere, which is heightened when you know its history.And Dean, who describes himself as a sceptic compared to Hazel who is a full believer in the paranormal, says doing investigations down here has opened his mind to the possibilities that there is something  out there.Hazel and Dean are kitted out with a box full of equipment, such as ious sound recorders, crucixes and even a ouija board, which they have bought from specialist shops and online.Tonight, they will be using a Meterk Meter, which uses an electro-magnetic fieldto seea presence is nearby and a Mel Meter  that measures EMF and temperature:a spirit is present people will often complain of a room going cold.They also have a K meter, which that can allow for communication from spooks by them manipulating the LED lights on the meter.The theory is, your soul carries on within electromagnetic fields, which is how spirits can communicate with us through these items, says Hazel.In Sun Onlines tool box are three iPhone apps.They are: Ghost Hunter M , Ghost Detect Proand Ghost Sensor , which is supposed to imitate the K meter.On first glance, the apps dont seem particularly great. They are packed full of ads, make a lot of weird bleeping noises and seem completely incomprehensible and impossible to use.And Im sceptical as to how an iPhone can even detect ghosts in the first place.When we ask Hazel what she thinks of the apps, she says theyre not as effective for ghost hunting as the experts equipment, as they can be affected by the phones own electrical fields.Shes right: as we walk round, not very much happens with the apps. Ghost Sensor does absolutely nothing, the needle remains still even when Deans K meter starts to spike.When I try out Ghost Detect Pro, I suddenly hear random words coming out of my phone: Wild! Grant! Fish!I wonderthis is a spirit trying to communicate, but Hazel assures me these are often randomised sounds assigned to the app for fun, which is a little bit disappointing.Our final room to try is a corridor with stairs leading up to the next level at the back of it. This, Hazel says, is the place where Spectrum have had the most activity.And it doesnt disappoint: Hazel and Deans equipment starts spiking and bleeping, and even the M app shows the EMF reading is jumping.The room suddenly falls extremely cold, before we hear it: somebody coming down the stairs very slowly, followed by banging sounds.With everyone accounted for, theres surely only one explanation for who it could be...If thats you, knock twice for yes, shouts Dean. And immediately, we hear two knocks coming from the other side of the room.To be honest, its so scary I forget to check my apps, but based on earlier I cant imagine they were doing very much.We wait to heartheres any more, but the weird atmosphere that had been in the room during the knocking lts, and Hazel whispers hes gone.Whether that was Mr Brackett or not, we will never know...Although I cant fully explain the spookiness down in disused station, or the footsteps and knocking we heard, I remain on the fence about ghosts.And as for the apps  Theyre best left to the professionals.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit budget changes
story: The major changes revealed by Philip Hammond this week to the new flagship system won’t come in for months, and are set to exclude some groups.The Chancellor said he would increase the work title: brexit deal latest theresa may brussels aides eu talks
story: Dominic Raab told MPs he expects the Brexit deal to be finalised by November , adding: The end is now firmly in sight.The pound soared as the news emerged today in a letter from Mr Raab to Hilary Benn, chair of the Commons Brexit committee.Negotiations between the UK and EU formally restarted in Brussels this week, raising hopes of a possible deal.Today Mr Benn published a letter sent by Mr Raab last week in which the minister predicted a deal would be done soon.He wrote: I would be happy to give evidence to the committee when a deal is finalised, and currently expect November  to be suitable.Mr Raab added: The end is now firmly in sight and, while obstacles remain, it cannot be beyond us to navigate them.We have resolved most of the issues and we are building up together what the future relationship should look like and making real progress.He said the main outstanding issue to be resolved in talks is the Northern Ireland backstop which is meant to rule out checks on the Irish border.No envoy Olly Robbins is meeting top Eurocrats this week - in a bid to strike an agreement as quickly as possible.The PM has been hoping to cut a deal in time for an emergency Brexit summit which could be held in mid-November.Mrs May wants to cut a deal based on her Chequers plan, which would see Britain continue to follow European rules for goods while setting new regulations on services.She could face a challenge getting the agreement through the House of Commons - but last night Tory rival David Davis suggested she would succeed.The ex-Brexit Secretary predicted MPs would be so scared of No Deal they might back whatever Mrs May proposed.Speaking at a think-tank event, he said: Terror will win. The fear of No Deal, I think - we havent had a chance to talk about it much - but I think thats an irrational fear of No Deal or WTO deal. That will win and there will be a deal.But a friend told The Sun: DD didnt mean PM WILL get a deal through Parliament, but MUST get a deal through Parliament.“He inferred she would secure a deal rather than a No Deal - but only Canada can get through, not Chequers.”Pressure on the Government to strike a deal could increase following a report that Britain will fall into recession without one.Rating agency SP today warned that a No Deal scenario would cause a spike in unemployment and inflation, as well as a house price crash.The firm predicted household incomes would fall by £, in the year after Britain left the EU without a withdrawal deal.More than , UK residents a month are applying to become citizens of the Republic of Ireland.Irish senator Neale Richmond said: Figures for the first half of  show the number of applications received by the embassy in London is already at ,.Embassy officials predict that based on this,  will be the busiest year so far for Irish passport applications in the UK.While many in the UK are concerned with the looming disaster of Brexit, we must seize the positives from this new wave of people reconnecting with their Irish heritage, our post-Brexit UK-Irish relations can be built on a strong, connected, diaspora.Before the Brexit referendum in , only half as many British people were applying for Irish passports.The figures dont include residents of Northern Ireland, who are automatically eligible for an Irish passport as well as a UK one.

title: when all saints day 2018 as all hallows day christians celebrate november 1
story: All Saints Day falls on November  - heres what its all about...All Saints’ Day always falls on November  – the day after Halloween.This year it falls on a Thursday.All Saints’ Day is also known as All Hallows’ Day, Hallowmas, Feast of All Saints and Solemnity of All Saints.“Hallow” means a saint, or somebody holy – hence All Hallows’ Day.The day is a Christian festival that honours all saints and martyrs, both known and unknown.Christian celebrate All Saints Day because they believe that there is a powerful spiritual bond between those in heaven , and the living .Believers attend church and try not to do any servile work.Remembering saints has been a Christian tradition since the fourth century AD, but it wasnt until AD that Pope Bonace IV decided to remember all martyrs.Originally, May  was the Feast of All Holy Martyrs, but in AD, Pope Gregory IV extended the festival to remember all saints and changed both its name to Feast of All Saints, as well as the date to November .In English-speaking countries, All Saints’ Day is traditionally celebrated with the hymn For All the Saints by Walsham How and by lighting candles of remembrance.In countries such as Mexico, Guatemala, Spain and Portugal offerings are made on the day and in Mexico the day also coincides with the Day Of The Dead, which last through October  to November .All Saints Day falls where it does because it marks the day after All Hallows Dayand before All Souls Day - which serves as a possibility to worship the faithful departed.The three are practices by Christians worldwide as a time for worship and remembrance. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 24 hour booze ban airports
story: The Home Office will launch a review into whether to extend high-street licensing laws into jam-packed terminals at Heathrow, Gatwick and other airports across the country.The move could see pubs, restaurants and duty free shops forced to delay serving booze until am – ending the “early morning pint” for holidaymakers and stag dos.Airlines have been demanding a change for months after a rise in booze-fuelled mid-air disturbances.Home Office Minister Victoria Atkins said “disruptive or drunk behaviour” in the skies was “unacceptable”.But furious pub chiefs accused the Government of “demonising” punters.And they claimed any crackdown could exempt posh passengers in first-class lounges – as the drinks are served for free by airlines.The Civil Aviation Authority earlier this summer claimed there were  reports of serious disruption on flights in , up from  in  and just  in .But airline industry chiefs claim there are thousands of incidents that fail to meet the CAA threshold.Ryanair demanded restrictions on alcohol sales – including a two-drink limit for passengers - after a pilot was forced to ert a plane bound for Ibiza in July.In August an inebriated man dressed as Peter Pan fairy character Tinkerbell was booted off a flight at Stansted by armed police after abusing cabin crew.Currently pubs and restaurants “airside” – after passport control – are exempt from the  Licensing Act which governs the high street. title: britain changes foreign aid rules
story: It means the £ million the UK spent on the Overseas Territories in the wake of last year’s Hurricane Irma could in future come from the overseas aid budget rather than asking taxpayers for extra.It is a big win for Ms Mordaunt after a y campaign to change international rules that govern what counts as foreign aid spending. But the International Development Secretary wants to loosen the strict rules further by allowing countries who are just above the threshold to qualy too.Currently Britain can only spend aid money on countries that have an average income per head of below £,.And we can’t send aid money to those countries even when they dip below the target again.But the rule change would allow those countries to once again become recipients of our aid moneyhumanitarian or economic disasters mean they fall below the World Bank High Income threshold.Countries that have fallen below the threshold since  after previously exceeding the threshold include Antigua and Barbuda, Equatorial Guinea and Venezuela.The strict rules - governed by the OECD’s Development Assistance Committee in Paris - stopped us using the bloated foreign aid budget on the reconstruction effort for Caribbean islands devastated by Hurricane Irma and Maria last year because the nations were deemed too wealthy.The tourism industry in the likes of St Lucia and the British Virgin Islands has taken a long-term hit by the tragedy. Britain had to use £ million from other government budgets to cover help with recovery.At the time of the hurricane there was no system in place for affected countries to requaly for aid.Hailing the victory, Ms Mordaunt told The Sun: “The British public are strong supporters of providing help in the wake of disasters, including long-term reconstruction. They want to help people, especially when they are from nations we have close ties to.“Not being able to pay for that help from the aid budget, because a nation’s economy was doing well, before a hurricane, earthquake or other disaster hit, was illogical and had to change.“Britain has never fallen short in our support of countries in need – either through sending aid, our Armed Forces or reconstruction support. This signicant rule change means that in future we may be able to use our aid budget to pay for that longer term, reconstruction support.“This gives the UK more options in how it can help a nation recover and become more resilient to shocks. title: ghost on a plane halloween
story: Francisco Hernandez, , was finishing his sht when he heard a mysterious bang on a pitch black aircraft and went to investigate.The security guard was clocking off at am when he was spooked by a sudden noise.And what he found on-board left him trembling with fear.In the horror clip, Francisco explores the dark plane, shining his torch down the aisle.As he gingerly looks around a shadowy figure springs out from around a corner.Francisco sees the apparition twice before he legs it out there.Of the creepy encounter he said: I entered the plane in the early hours of the morning as part of the airline’s protocol and was following procedures of inspecting the cabin.I had heard what sounded like someone slamming doors inside the air plane and went to check it out.“At first I wasn’t sure what I was seeing. title: paraplegic told never walk spinal implants

title: sir jim ratcliffe brexit sovereignty
story: Ineos boss Sir Jim Ratclfe said he disliked the “drama”surrounding the negotiations saying it was simply a matter of organising a “sensible trade deal”.The petrochemicals boss with a £billion fortune - a long standing supporter of Brexit - spoke as he received his knighthood at Buckingham Palace.He said: “I don’t think it should have been the world’s biggest challenge to negotiate Brexit really because you’re just taking sovereignty back.“You’re trying to organise a sensible trade deal ... and, you know, we’ve got the old relationships.”We stepped in in the war and sacriced a lot of people and a lot of our economy, on our own behalf, but also on other people’s behalf in Europe.“I don’t see why reaching an agreement with our European colleagues should be so dficult. We ought to just be able to get there in a sensible way. There’s a lot of drama around, which I don’t like.Askedhe though British negotiators were to blame, he said: “I don’t want to say that. I’m not close enough to the detail to be honest.”But he insisted it should be logical to come to a sensible deal adding: “All we’re doing is saying ‘Germany you can sell your products in England and we’d like to sell our products in Germany’.“Mercedes want to sell Mercedes over here. And we might want to sell Savile Row suits in Germany.“I’ve always been of the view that I was always in favour of the common market, which is where it all began, which is free trade amongst our European colleagues.“But I don’t believe in the UK sovereignty being handed over to Brussels. title: lion air flight black box recovered wreckage indonesia sea
story: The flight recorder could provide clues to what happened after the still new plane lost contact with ground staff just  minutes after taking off on Monday.Indonesian ers found the box among debris in the mud on the sea floor and brought it back to a ship on the surface today.Navy st Sgt. Hendra toldTV: I was desperate because the current below was strong but I am confident of the tools given to me.I started digging and cleaning the debris until I finally found an orange object.He confirmed it was intact without saying whether it was the flight data recorder or the cockpit voice recorder, which are both usually referred to as black boxes.WHAT WE KNOW SO FAR:Only small pieces of the aircraft had been found, the er said, adding that the search had gradually closed in on the black box.The planes black boxes should help explain why the almost-new Boeing  MAX  jet went down in waters about  metresdeep just off Jakarta.It was the worst airline disaster in Indonesia since  and renewed concerns about safety in its fast-growing aviation industry, which was recently removed from European Union and U.S. blacklists.Data from flight-tracking sites show the plane had erratic speed and altitude in the early minutes of a flight on Sunday and on its fatal flight Monday.Safety experts caution, however, that the data must be checked for accuracy against the flight data recorder.Several passengers on the Sunday flight from Bali to Jakarta have recounted problems that included a long-delayed takeoff for an engine check and terrying descents in the first  minutes in the air.A ping sound believed to be emitted by one of the black boxes had been getting clearer, Haryo Satmiko, deputy chief of the national transport safety , said earlier on Thursday.An underwater drone had detected an object suspected to be part of the fuselage, he added.A team of ers had gone down since am to map the area where the black box is thought to be, Haryo said, describing sea conditions as normal.Strong currents on Tuesday hampered the search, with the effort further complicated by the presence of energy pipelines nearby.However, officials had said they were confident they were searching in the right area, having found items, such as le jackets, trousers and magazines, thought to be from the plane.If found, the fuselage would be lted using a crane, because of the many bodies likely to be trapped inside, Muhammad Syaugi, the chief of Indonesias search and rescue agency, said on Tuesday.

title: these creepy fish with no eyes are freaking everyone out so what are they
story: A short video of the fish was shared on social media earlier this week and has gone viral - with many asking what the odd amphibians are.In the clip, shared by @BaconLava, the strange black fish are plucked from the water and appear to squirm between the fingers of a persons hand.The odd shaped heads of the fish resemble blackberries with a bubble-like appearance their mouths open and close in the footage.The video titled Black Oranda Goldfish quickly went viral, racking up almost , retweets and over , likes - but many users were still baffled over their likeness to blackberries.One user questioned: You mean to say this isn’t a living blackberry.Glinda said: “That aren’t fish. They are blackberries from Chernobyl.”AshTheBluntBoo said: These look like swimming blackberries with mouths.User JonRud added: I put blackberries in my oatmeal this morning. Now I cant consciously make that decision again.While another said the fish were so cute adding: He looks like a swimming allergic reaction.And Mara Vercetti said: This is fascinating and disgusting at the same time.Sharing a picture of a three-eyed fish from The Simpsons, @CubaEscobar said: The Simpson’s are at it again with the predictions.The Black Oranda Goldfish is a breed of goldfish characterised by a prominent bubble-like hood on their heads and may either appear as a prominent growth on the top of the head or may encase the entire face except for the eyes and mouth.The Black Oranda is one of many ieties of what is known as ornamental or fancy goldfish and is originally from parts of Asia, Japan, and China.Orandas are available in a iety of colours, most often orange, red, black, blue, bronze, white and black and white.

title: leicester city fans love vichai for his deeds not his words
story: And then, just as we were getting used to Raksriaksorn, it changed again to something even more unpronounceable. Srivaddhanaprabha - a title bestowed on the -year-old entrepreneur by the Thai royal family, in recognition of his success and philanthropy.Its hard to form a close bond with someone whose name you cant pronounce and have to Google to spell. But we did that at Leicester City Football Club. We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha.We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha not just for who he was - but because of who he wasnt.We loved him not only for what he did - but what he didnt do. The footballing landscape has been ruined by owners who take clubs as playthings, get bored and run them into the ground. You dont need me to tell you who they are. We all know.We knew the dference, at Leicester City Football Club, between good owners and bad ones.Wed lived through the alternative.Wed had owners who didnt care.Wed had owners who couldnt club together the #, needed to buy a former midfield favourite who wanted toto the club. This wasnt the s. It was just over a decade ago.Wed had owners whose grip on the LCFC purse string was so careless it plunged the club into administration.Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha was not like that. When he arrived at Leicester in the summer of , he bought the club from Milan Mandaric. There was concern in some quarters that because Mandaric had sealed the deal then maybe this new Thai chap was cut from the same cloth.He wasnt.If Mandaric was all about hiring and firing and shooting from the hip in pt back page headlines - and, oh boy, he was - then Khun Vichai, to give him his conventional Thai title, was the opposite of that. I was a feature writer at the Leicester Mercury when Vichai arrived. I did all sorts of features about Leicester City during my time there. I never interviewed him. Few people did.He didnt do many interviews. He didnt want to and he didnt have to. So he didnt. He preferred to do what he had to do and stay, unnoticed, in the background.

title: dont give money beggars give
story: NewsDont give money to beggars, give it to homelessness fund says Labours Andy BurnhamThousands of pounds, handed over with the best of intentions, is not going where it is most needed says Mayor of Greater ManchesterShareCommentsByPaul Byrne:,  NOV NewsHomeless Kevin and Lisa, at the new night shelter for the homeless in Ardwick Manchester "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Labours Andy Burnham wants people to stop giving money to beggars – and put the cash towards his homeless project instead.He fears thousands of pounds, handed over with the best of intentions, is not going where it is most needed.And he is putting his money where his heart is – by giving % of his own salary to his homelessness fund, in an effort to solve the issue. Today he is calling on the public to help him.Many homeless people currently rely on donations given to them by the public in the street or on shytransport, for food and shelter. But too often cash is creamed off by criminals who exploit them. Some is blown by vulnerable rough sleepers on drugs or alcohol before, as intended, it can be spent at a hostel on a bed. Some money even ends up in the pockets of professional beggars whoto a warm home each night after a hard day’s scrounging. So today Mr Burnham, the Mayor of Greater Manchester, is launching a project called A Bed Every Night to ensure the homeless are not just given emergency accommodation when temperatures plummet below freezing.The plan is also backed by Manchester City skipper Vincent Kompany, who is donating some funds from his testimonial year. But there’s a shortfall, shyestimated at around poundmillion, and Mr Burnham hopes the public can meet it. The mayor, who has pledged to shyeradicate rough sleeping in the region, said: “The best way to help people this winter is to give through the official routes rather than give on the street. “Not everybody out there in the day time is necessarily someone who will be sleeping rough at night. “The clear message is there are people out there using public shysentiment and concerns about homelessness – and trying to make money out of it. “I think there is a lot of money given that is not going to the right places.” Homelessness official Mike Wright said: “There are gangs, mainly lower level drug dealers, that prey on beggars and rough sleepers in Manchester.” He said some homeless victims even end up as drug-runners for the thugs. He added: “They allow them to have a ‘begging patch’ and not be beaten upthey do ‘this, this or this’. “They take their passports off them and their National Insurance number and say ‘you work for us’.”  At least  people are believed to be rough sleeping across the region. Last year’s Beast from the East meant day after day of sub-zero temperatures so more people took up emergency shyaccommodation for longer. There they were given extra assistance. Mr Burnham said: “There was a chance to give them the extra support which was more likely to keep them off the streets for good.” The mayor’s plan has been backed by businesses, charities, councils and volunteers. Already around  beds have been provided in night shelters, hostels and other accommodation, with more expected soon. Insisting the scheme is more than just a “sticking plaster”, Mr Burnham added: “We remain % committed to ending the need for rough sleeping by  and are on the verge of a massive step towards it with A Bed Every Night. “Our aim is to provide a place for every person sleeping rough from today right through to March .” He added: “Ideally, it will provide a steady base with a hot shower, hot meal and specialist support.”Visit www.bedeverynight
