title: tory mp calls labour aide
story: NewsTory MP calls for Labour aide and son of shadow minister who took £ of drugs to Bestival to lose his Commons passIshmael Osamor works as a communications aide for his mum Kate OsamorShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video tory-mp-calls-labour-staffer-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory MP has called for a Labour aide and son of shadow minister who took pound of drugs to a music festival to lose his House of Commons pass. Ishmael Osamor, who resigned as a Labour councillor on Tuesday night, admitted three charges of possessing drugs with intent to supply and a fourth charge of possession at last years Bestival event in Dorset. The -year-old works for his mum who is shadow secretary of state for International Development Kate Osamor. He was caught with ecstasy, cocaine, ketamine and cannabis at the music festival in August , nine months before he was elected as a councillor. In his resignation letter his insisted his friends and family were unaware of the charges - including his mum who spoke in his favour during the selection process when he was picked as a Labour council cabinet. Today Tory MP Simon Hoare expressed concern that someone convicted of drugs offences was able to hold on to his parliamentary pass which gives him access to the Houses of Parliament - but he did not name Mr Osamor. He said: We are all alert to the scourge of drugs in our towns and cities. But I also think the House would agreethe sins of the father and the mother cant be visited on the sons then the same is true but in reverse. Raising a point of order MrHoare said: But there is a case, as youll be aware, currently alive and alert in the media about passholders, or a passholder of this place, which is after all an honour not a right, who has been found guilty of drugs-related crime. He asked what the procedure was for examining whether the pass should be taken away.  The Speaker John Bercow told MPs that it was up to him whether staff were able to keep their passes after such an issue had been raised. But Mr Bercow reminded MPs that ideally any complaint would be raised privately. Osamor, who was elected in May to Haringey council, apologised for the unwanted attention his case had brought. He was sentenced to a two-year community order and  days rehabilitation, last Friday. According to expenses records filed with the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority website, his role as Kate Osamors communications officer paid between pound, and pound, in  . In a statement to the councils chief executive he said: It is with great regret that I am offering this as formal notice of my resignation as councillor, effective immediately. I would like to take the opportunity to apologise to the council, as I have to my ward colleagues and residents, for the unwelcome attention my case has brought to Haringey. Councillor Joseph Ejiofor, council leader, said: Councillor Osamor came to see me on Friday  October and explained about an incident that happened in September last year. I expressed my concern and disappointment by the actions that he had admitted. The Labour Party expects high standards from its elected representatives, and I know that Councillor Osamor has taken some personal time over the past four days to review whether his actions have met this expectation. Consequently, Ishmael has decided to resign from Haringey Council. We respect his decision.

A video of the vehicle outside an Aldi store in Livingston, West Lothian was posted online. It left people askingit was physically possible for the red Toyota to have made its way into the space. The clip was captured as Matthew Bestwick drove past the bizarre scene yesterday, the Daily Record reports. Matthews son, Ryan, eight, filmed while the drain engineer cruised passed the wreck which had been attended to by police around .pm.  Matthew posted the video on Facebook yesterday saying: Just when you think somethings arent possible. The clip starts by showing a police car parked by the side of the road in the Aldi car park. story: NewsControlling boyfriend tried to keep partner as his virginal sex robot and held her captive for weekChristopher Cooksey called his ex-partners work to say she had been in a car crash, after he had badly beaten herShareCommentsByAdam HaleLiz DayKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsChristopher Cooksey, , flew into a rage after he scrolled through her phone "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA violent thug wanted to keep his partner as his virginal sex robot and held her hostage.Christopher Cooksey ruthlessly beat up his girlfriend and held her captive for a week to hide her injuries.The brute began abusing her after becoming jealous of her previous relationships. A court heard the -year-old started a relationship with Stephanie Watkis, , after meeting her in a gym in September , but weeks later he carried out the first of a string of attacks on her. In one incident in December he found a picture on her phone of a man she had been interested in two years previously. Cooksey, from Pontypool, Gwent, repeatedly punched her while she lay in bed, leaving her with a black eye and a bruised arm before forcing her to drink a bottle of rum. He then kept her as his prisoner for a week to hide her physical injuries and used her phone to tell her employers she would be off work following a car crash.  He also controlled Miss Watkis choice of clothes and make-up, and stole her phone, cutting her off from family and friends after she moved into his flat and rendering her utterly dependent on him. Today, prosecutor Roger Grfiths read a victim impact statement from Miss Watkis, who said she has been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder and depression because of the violent relationship. Miss Watkis said: He always used to say this is not a game and thats what I hear in my nightmares. Hes hugely impacted my social skill and Im now very distrustful of people. Before, I was a bubbly, friendly and welcoming person. I was carefree. This is no longer the case.  Cooksey was found guilty of two counts of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, common assault and  imprisonment following a trial at Newport Crown Court. Harry Baker, defending, told the court at the sentencing hearing that Cooksey had no previous convictions, and both his client and Miss Watkis had admitted it was a bad relationship. Judge Thomas Crowther QC said Cooksey became obsessed with how many other men Miss Watkis had slept with before him. He said: It became very quickly clear that you had a fragile ego, a thin-skinned nature and a vile temper. I have no doubt you wanted Miss Watkis to be your partner, but not as a human, a woman, but rather as a canvas upon which you could project your fantasy image of a woman who had no history, no past, no family, no interest except you.  She didnt match your desire for some blank virginal sex robot. You attacked her, punching her as she lay on the floor curled into a ball, as she put it, like a dog. You isolated her within your home. You made her subject to your dominance.You enforced that by ruthless violence, using your physical power to subjugate her, and by demeaning behaviour. You have caused serious physical and enduring psychological harm. You drove her to the brink of tragedy. Cooksey was given a six-year extended sentence, meaning he will spend four in custody before he is released on licence. He was also given a -year restraining order in relation to Miss Watkis.

story: NewsKate Middleton reads letters relating to great-grandmothers three brothers who all died in WWIThe Duchess of Cambridge was shown a postcard written by her great-great-uncle Lionel where he writes I am quite well before he was killed in action on the same day, age ShareCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsBefore looking at the letters, the Duchess will take a short tour of the First World War Galleries "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge has read emotional letters relating to her great-grandmothers three brothers who all fought and died in the First World War. Ahead of Armistice Day, the Duchess visited the Imperial War Museum, in London, to view poignant documents which reveal an account of le and death in the trenches. Francis Martineau Lupton, the Duchess’s great-great-grandfather, had five children. The two youngest brothers, Captain Maurice Lupton and Lieutenant Lionel M Lupton went to France within three days of each other in . The eldest Lupton brother, Major Francis A Lupton fought with the th Battalion West Yorkshire Regiment in . Sadly, each of the brothers was killed in action over a period of three years: Maurice in , Lionel in  and Francis in .  One letter of condolence was sent to Kate Middletons family from George V, who wrote: The King realises that this is the third beloved son you have given to your Country’s cause, and His Majesty trusts that you may be granted strength and comfort in the further sorrow which you have been called upon to bear. Another, a telegram from the young mens father Lieutenant Richard Noel Middleton, informed the rest of the family about Francis death. It reads: Bad News Francis Body Found Near Taylor’s Killed Instantaneously Bomb Saw Norman Yesterday And Grave In Churchyard. The other items included a field service postcard from Lionel dated  July , where he writes: I am quite well. Sadly, Lionel was killed in action on the same day, aged just .  In the galleries, the Duchess met historians, curators and the fellow descendant of a First World War soldier. And after leaving the First World War Galleries, she proceeded to IWMs Explore History room, which is a drop-in research and work space at IWM London. She was shown several documents that relate to her relatives experiences of le on the Front, including a letter of condolence from the Keeper of the Privy Purse at Buckingham Palace.  Kate also read her great-grandmother Olives registration card. Olive and her younger sister Anne were both VAD nurses with the British Red Cross during the war. The Duchess of Cambridge was last seen yesterday when she joined Prince William to meet young apprentices inspiring a community with sport. Kate was stylishly dressed in a pair of black skinny jeans with a grey blazer jacket and black polo neck jumper for the event at the Basildon Sporting Village, in Essex. William wore a dark blue fleece with navy trousers. The royal couple chatted to children and shook hands with their fans as they arrived, before hearing from graduates of the Coach Core scheme. Coach Core was launched to inspire youngsters with sport and create the next generation of coaches who will themselves go on to influence their communities in future generations.

story: NewsMeghan Markle and Prince Harrys Royal Tour - Amazing little moments you might have missed from couples adventureMeghan Markle and Prince Harrys Royal Tour  including lots of official occasions, but there were also some very sweet unplanned moments along the wayShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  OCT NewsIts been a very special tour "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry certainly made their first Royal Tour one to remember, with -days filled with fun and exciting engagements. title: moment brit tourists stage revolt
story: NewsMoment Brit tourists stage revolt after TUI dump them . miles from hotel in rain stormThe group of  holidaymakers had their flight delayed and were dropped at the wrong emergency hotel in Agadir, MoroccoShareCommentsByElaine McCahillJohn Glover:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video brit-tourists-stage-revolt-after-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a group of British holidaymakers staged a revolt after TUI dumped them one-and-a-half miles away from their hotel in the lashing rain. The group of  people had been delayed for hours and then forced to drag their cases to their hotel in storm-hit Agadir, Morocco. It all kicked off when the exhausted travellers were dropped off at the wrong place, at which point they realised the coach had left with a sleeping child on board. The seven-year-old was ed an hour later and the group, which included elderly and disabled travellers as well as families with prams, were forced to trudge through the soaked streets to their hotel. When they finally arrived at the right hotel at .am, they found most of the rooms were not available, there was nothing to eat or drink, and bedding wasnt ready in some of the rooms that were free. One traveller had an asthma attack climbing the stairs and an ambulance was called.  An angry showdown with a TUI rep occurred the following morning and footage shows the leader of the tourists demanding they are treated like human beings, prompting a massive round of applause. The group had been due to leave Morocco on October  toto Manchester Airport. But serious technical problems with the .pm flight meant they were sent back to Agadir at .am, arriving at .am. But the coach driver dropped the passengers a mile and a half from their emergency hotel accommodation and left before the mistake was realised - taking the seven-year-old boy as well. Passenger Phil Harrison, , from Adlington, Lancashire, recorded the scenes as the tourists tramped through Agadir in a rain storm looking for their accommodation. The clip starts with the sound of thunder and lightning and cuts to Phil saying: “Still walking down the same road. Still not a bleeding rep greeted by anybody. Absolutely disgusting.” The camera then pans around to show tired children dragging suitcases with some mothers carrying their children and a angry tourist shouts while dragging her suitcase: “Women with children. They’re lucky to save this.”  Phil, who emerged as the leader of the group, then goes back to narrating the clip saying “women with children pulling cases. Absolutely disgusting. TUI you are out of order.” The clip then cuts to tourists arriving at the hotel at about .am, tired, soaking and struggling to pull their luggage up the steps. The person filming the clip can be heard panting heavily. The video cuts to the following morning and Phil is filmed addressing a TUI rep, detailing their numerous complaints. To deafening applause and clapping from the dozens of weary travellers, he passionately concludes: From every colour, including race, it doesnt matter, we are all human beings here and we all deserve an explanation! The group finally ed to Manchester at pm on October , a delay admitted by TUI of  hours and  minutes. Zuzana Mestour-Tenkova, , from Manchester, said today: My seven-year old-son was left behind asleep in the coach in that big chaos, due to misunderstanding between me and my husband.  “It was a terrible experience. I still feel sick just thinking about it. We are so disappointed with the way TUI handled this whole situation. Its just disgusting.” Michele Cutts, , from Sheffield, said: “We were traumatised, frantic with worry and let down by TUI. Our families could not get any information on our flight, nothing was announced, it caused unnecessary, in some cases necessary worry on their part. And Esther Mashana said: “I thought it disgusting how we were all denied our basic human rights like water and food. “I remember in the morning I was thirsty. I asked for water at the reception and was told to go to the shops to buy water. “Absolutely appalling. I think its safe to say I wont be using TUI again. Neither will I recommend them to anyone.” A spokeswoman for TUI UK said: “We’re sorry to hear about these customers’ experience. We’ll be looking in to the matter as a priority and will follow up appropriately.”

title: russell bishop trial witness describes
story: NewsRussell Bishop trial: Witness describes haunting moment he found bodies of Babes in Woods victims, Kevin Rowland shouted out "s**t, I think weve found them" as the bodies of nine-year-olds Nicola Fellows and Karen Hadaway were spottedShareByTom Pettor:,  OCT NewsKaren Hadaway was found dead in bushes in Wild Park in Moulsecoomb on the outskirts of Brighton "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA hospital porter has told a jury how he found the bodies of two murdered girls, dubbed the “Babes in the Woods,” in an isolated den  years ago. Kevin Rowland was just  when he joined the search for nine-year-old friends Nicola Fellows and Karen Hadaway after they disappeared on October , . Mr Rowland said he spotted a pink or purple jumper and the side of a young girls face who looked like she was asleep in Wild Park, half a mile from their homes on the edge of Brighton. He said: I stopped because I knew there was a young girl there and I did not want to go any further. His first words were: S**t, I think weve found them. He was giving evidence at the trial of Russell Bishop, who is accused of sexually assaulting the pair and strangling them. Mr Rowland said Bishop had joined the search and had to be restrained from approaching the dead girls.  He said: He tried to step over me but I put my arm out to stop him. Newspaper reports at the time described the girls as looking like little dolls and cuddling asasleep, the Old Bailey was told. But Mr Rowland, who was with his friend Matthew Marchant, denied going close enough to see them both properly. They were joined by Pc Paul Smith - nicknamed Smudge - two or three minutes later, he said. Mr Marchant was given a police helmet and sent off to wave it to get help, jurors heard. Pc Smith then crawled through undergrowth to reach the girls while Mr Rowland and Bishop stayed put, jurors heard. On his , Pc Smith radioed in to say he had checked each girl but found no pulse, the court heard. It was claimed on Bishops behalf that Mr Rowland and his friend had both looked at girls bodies.  Defence barrister Joel Bennathan QC also alleged that Bishop had gone up to where the bodies were and felt for a pulse. The witness repeatedly denied it, saying: Absolutely not. Mr Rowland was quizzed about an interview he gave to Brightons Evening Argus newspaper in which he described the girls as lying cuddling like they were asleep, their arms around each other. On being asked how he knew that, he said: I had no idea they were cuddling. I did not see they were cuddling. Cuddling sounded compassionate to me at the time. I may have heard that from other sources by the time I gave the interview. Mr Rowland spoke to the reporter after Nicolas father Barrie visited his home. He told jurors: Barrie was crying. He was in a real mess. I thought it would make him feel better. I think I said that to the Evening Argus because I said that to Barrie.  Giving evidence, Mr Marchant said he saw the top half of one of the girls but did not go to her. He said: Her eyes were closed asshe was asleep. The lawyer asked about a News of the World interview in which the Babes in the Wood victims were described as like little dolls, one lying on top with arm wrapped round the other. Mr Marchant denied saying that to the journalist, adding: Whatever is in that newspaper is not true. Bishop, now , originally from Brighton, has denied two charges of murder. He was cleared of the murders in  but the Court of Appeal had ordered a fresh trial in light of new DNA evidence. Some three years after his acquittal, Bishop was convicted of the kidnap, indecent assault and attempted murder of a seven-year-old girl at Devils Dyke, also on the South Downs. The trial continues.

title: callum booth keen to keep feelgood factor going at dundee united
story: Callum Booth is delighted to see everyone associated with Dundee United pulling in the same direction and he’s determined to reward today’s travelling support with more to cheer at Dunfermline.The Tangerines head to East End Park today for new manager Robbie Neilson’s third match in charge.Despite only being in charge for a couple of weeks now, United left-back Booth says the new gaffer has already made quite an impression.He said: “It’s been brilliant, really good. Training has been really good and I thinkyou asked any of the boys in the changing-room we’d all be the same.“It’s really gone up a level, we’re all enjoying it and I think that shows on a Saturday.“It’s been quite tough but I think we needed that. It’s been enjoyable at the same time, though, and we’re all buying into his ideas.”Off the field there seems to be an air of optimism around Tannadice but Booth knows getting results on the pitch is the only way to realise their hopes of promotion.And that means keeping their unbeaten run under the new boss going against a Dunfermline side that have already bagged a deserved win over the Tangerines.Booth added: “Four points from the first two games isn’t too bad but I think they were two good performances as well.“We feel hard done by we didn’t get the win over Inverness – I think most people there would agree with that but it wasn’t to be.“At least we put in a really positive performance and everyone is pulling in the same direction.“There is a good feel about the place and, hopefully, we can kick on now and go on a little run.“The players, coaching staff, fans all seem to be pulling in the same direction especially since the new gaffer has come in.“A thousand fans down at Partick, great backing and then same again last weekend. The fans were right with us until the last minute.“It does help, it makes a massive dference and Dunfermline isn’t too far down the road so I’d expect another good away following.“I think the fans can see the work and effort we’re putting in, evenwe didn’t get the three points last Saturday.“The fans have been great and long may it continue.”Allan Johnston’s Pars have been struggling of late after a lightning fast start to the season saw them follow up four wins from four in the Betfred Cup group stage with an impressive - victory at Tannadice.Since then, Dunfermline have only managed eight points from the following eight games and were beaten - at home last weekend despite dominating against Queen of the South.In fact, scoring goals at home has been a real problem of late with just the two Championship strikes going in.Booth  Co., however, are wary of a repeat show from the Pars.He said: “Dunfermline were really good at Tannadice the first time we played them and thoroughly deserved to win.“I think most people would be surprised they’ve not kicked on from that first game.“They played well that day and deserved the win.“I’ve not seen much of them since but it’s not worked out for them since for whatever reason.“They’ll still be a dangerous opponent, though, because they are, obviously, capable of putting in a performance but have just been a bit inconsistent recently.“If we go about it like we have done in the last two games then we’ll give ourselves a chance.“We’ll be going there in positive spirits, try to take our chances and come back up the road with the three points.”

title: cctv was down as man crossed tracks
story: Transport police are unable to investigate a trespassing incident on railway lines at Kirkcaldy because ScotRail’s CCTV system was rebooting at the time it happened.A man crossed the tracks twice at around .pm on Tuesday October .There were a number of people waiting at the station at the time, including children. Despite it happening just outside the station’s waiting areas, there is no footage of the incident.Mid Scotland and Fe MSP Claire Baker said the fact a trespassing incident at the station could go unrecorded raised questions.“Considering the current catchphrase at stations across the country is ‘see it, say it, sorted’, many passengers would be shocked to learn that ScotRail was unable to see anything at the time of a major incident,” said the Labour MSP.ScotRail said CCTV coverage is in place at the station but the system went down for about a quarter of an hour about the time of the incident while computers were rebooting. The CCTV blackout means it is virtually impossible to identy the man, who jumped down from  two and crossed the tracks.He then entered the station building and used the toilet facilities, before crossing the tracks for a second time and leaving by the exit at  two.

title: disco time as dundee city centres christmas light night moves to different day
story: It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas in Dundee, as the date for the city’s festive celebration has been set.The Christmas Light Night is ing to the city on Saturday November  – moving from its usual Friday night slot.The free festivities will be taking place throughout the city centre from pm onwards.Albert Square will be the place to take your young ones, with a disco, big screen, a bar serving hot drinks and a hot chocolate stand.The McManus will play host to a wall of light, where children can make a wish and light a candle.A torchlight procession will also parade through the city, with members of the public being encouraged to join in.Participants will gather at Dundee High School at pm.The procession will follow a “Wind and Water” theme, with lanterns made by community groups.Traditional hand-held torches can be carried by members of the public over the age of .The moment everyone will have been waiting for is set to take place at .pm, when the Christmas lights are switched on in City Square.People will then get a chance to “strip the willow”, with a ceilidh taking place in the square from -.pm.The traditional dance is free to attend and music will be provided by Fe ceilidh band, Skyrie.Anyone looking for more information on the lantern workshops has been encouraged to email cityevents@dundeecity.gov.uk.For those who would like to carry a torch, wristbands can be collected in advance from Dundee Box Office in City Square.Councillor Roisin Smith, depute convener of the Children and Families Service, said: “The Christmas Light Night is always good, with lots to see and activities to take part in.“Families have always enjoyed the event and its a great way to mark the start of the build–up to Christmas.”

title: dundee crematorium services to be broadcast around the world in 400k investment
story: Services at Dundee Crematorium are to be broadcast to families and friends around the world.A “video tribute” facility is being installed as part of a six-figure refurbishment of the crematorium.A temporary chapel has also been erected in the grounds to ensure an uninterrupted service.Funeral directors and operators Dignity are investing £, in the upkeep of the building.Among the improvements are new lighting fixtures inside the chapel, improved exterior finishing and new carpets, curtains and decor inside.Parts of the refurbishment have already been completed, with improvements made to public areas.Inside the chapel itself, work is now under way to create the “video tribute” facility, which will also include live–streaming technology.As the work takes place, Dignity has created a professional temporary chapel in the car park to host services in the meantime.It has a solid floor and walls and a dedicated PA system.Manager Vincent Millar said: “In the long term, residents will have a modern crematorium that provides a fitting venue for them to say a last farewell to their loved ones.“While it’s important we update the chapel, we believe it’s crucial to continue providing a service.“We recognise that many people want their funeral to take place in Dundeethey have always lived in the city.“The alternative option to the temporary chapel would have been to close the crematorium for  weeks while the work takes place, leaving bereaved families to arrange a funeral where.”Some disruption is to be expected, given that the temporary chapel takes up part of the car park, but families are being given longer to hold services to compensate for any disruption.The works are expected to be completed by the end of the year.

title: dundee gaffer says belief is key if dark blues have any hope of a result against celtic
story: ‘Start like you mean to go on’ is an over-used cliche but it’s exactly what boss Jim McIntyre wants from his side against Celtic tonight – providing they begin a lot better than they did in the - loss to Hearts.Last week at Dens, the Dark Blues were behind within two minutes after conceding a sloppy free-kick and immediately gave themselves an uphill struggle. One which ended in an easy victory for the Jambos.Tonight they welcome champions Celtic fresh off a - win of their own over that same Hearts team in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.It’s fair to say the odds are not in Dundee’s favour but that won’t stop the Dens gaffer giving his team the belief they can cause an upset.To get anything, though, he knows they can’t afford another sloppy start to the game.He said: “It’s so important to give ourselves a chance at the start.“Until Hearts scored their second goal, we did a lot of things good in the game though nobody seems to be interested in that.“We got into some good positions but didn’t punish them and lost another silly goal.“You think you have all the men in place to deal with it but you don’t.“It is very important we start the game well and grow into the game, that’s always the case whenever you play the Old Firm.“That is the aim, to get off to a good start.“I was at Murrayfield on Sunday and I thought Hearts were excellent for  minutes until the penalty but that’s what Celtic do – they constantly pose you questions.“Your concentration levels have to be tip-top and I felt after they got their goal that fluency they have came back.“Celtic are starting to hit their top level and you could see that with the quality of the goals.“To be able to keep that concentration level for -plus minutes is very, very dficult.“To beat them you have to have your organisation levels spot on, you’ve got to have one to  playing out of their skin and you hope a few of them aren’t quite at their peak.“It’s like anything, the favourites don’t always win and that’s the belief you have to go into the game with.“I’ve been at other clubs where we’ve gone and got a result against them and that’s the belief you’ve got to carry against them.“Equally, having said that, you know you are going to have to do everything really well and hope a few of their players are off it.”By the time January comes around, expectations are there will be a raft of changes in the Dens squad.However, Jim insists every player at his disposal right now will get the chance to show he’s good enough to help the side get out of relegation trouble.For the new gaffer, though, it’s not just about showing you’ve the ability to play at this level, it’s about proving you have the character to do so, too.He added: “I think this squad, with no disrespect to the Ross County squad that I inherited, definitely has more ability within it overall.“Ability alone isn’t enough – you’ve got to be able to do the hard yards and carry your job out. That is so important and good teams will punish youyou don’t.“It’s so important to have a good shape about you and do your jobs well at this level.“We have seen what happens when you drop runners at set-plays and give away silly free-kicks.“I think there is plenty of character in this dressing-room but it’s about knowing what’s required of you and standing up to do it.”

title: tom duthie dundee uniteds high pressing game can only click if every player is working hard
story: A feature of Dundee United under Robbie Neilson has been the high-pressing game he’s introduced since taking over early this month.Under previous boss Csaba Laszlo, the Tangerines tended to be a side who dropped off and retreated inside their own half when they lost possession.The key to that strategy was not to give other teams the ball and, for a while, the game stats were showing Laszlo’s United were dominating it.As time passed and things started going wrong, increasingly that became a problem. Other outfits in the Championship quickly worked out while getting the ball quickly was an option,that wasn’t on they’d have time to get the ball under control and pass their way up the pitch.As Partick Thistle, Inverness Caley Thistle and now Dunfermline have discovered, it’s been all change under the new manager.When his team lose the ball they will work hard, fast and high up the pitch to get it back as quickly as possible.That brought them their goals in Robbie’s opening game at Firhill, when for both strikes home players actually had good possession in their own half but were caught out by the speed with which they were closed down.And in the draw against ICT and in Saturday’s win over the Pars, a feature of United’s play was the number of times they won the ball back in, or near, the opponent’s defensive third.Watching from the stands, what is striking about the new policy is the amount of ground it involves the attacking players covering. At the sharp end has been Pavol Safranko. Fortunately for United, as well as being a talented goalscorer, the Slovakian prides himself on his work-rate.At the weekend he almost literally ran himself into the ground – going down with cramp in injury time and being forced off.Not far behind have been the attacking midfield trio of Paul McMullan, Fraser Aird and Billy King. As well as being expected to get forward and get on the ball, there is little respite for them when the other team’s defenders have it.Delighted as he’s been with that quartet’s attitude to a side of the game creative players do not always relish, Robbie stressed the system only works and will continue to,every outfield player buys into it.One chink in the armour though and he knows it will fall apart, allowing the other team to find men with space and time to hurt United.“Pavol’s been great. I know that he’s a very good player and, as I’ve said, I knew about him before I came here because I’d seen him play at Aalborg ,” said the gaffer.“But we also have McMullan, King, Aird, the boys behind, doing a lot of running as well.“And I’m a big believer that when we go and press, even when we’re attacking, the defence have got a big role to play in it as well.“If we’re asking forward players to go and run , ,  yards to go and press people, then the midfielders and defenders have to do it as well.“There is a responsibility on them to go and do it as well. As a team we are getting better at it, but it’s early days, we’re only three games in.”That note of caution possibly stems from the fact, although he’s been pleased with the way the players have taken to the tactic, the next couple of weeks could provide sterner tests of it.Partick and the Pars have been struggling for form and while Inverness remain the only unbeaten second tier team, as five of them in a row indicates, they have become the draw specialists of the ision.Up next are Queen of the South and leaders Ross County, two sides who might just be better equipped to cope with the high press.

title: tom duthie neil mccann tried to change too much too soon at dundee
story: When Neil McCann looks back on his time as Dundee boss he will surely learn several lessons, ones that can stand him in good steadhe s to management.Perhaps the most obvious will be that, whatever your football philosophy, it has to be tapered to suit the resources you have available when it comes to players.McCann’s mantra at Dens was to play passing football at all times and, ultimately, at all costs. That led to too many goals being lost by errors as, at high risk, the ball was played out from the back.It became increasingly clear some of his defenders in particular were not comfortable with this policy but the manager was not for budging and persevered with the style of play he was convinced would, ultimately, bring success.The number of goals it cost made it inevitable what many saw as stubbornness was what cost McCann his job.That is, perhaps, an over-simplication and, now the dust has settled on the former Scotland international’s departure, a more in-depth look throws up other factors.A look at the players he used in his eight Premiership games in charge this term highlights another couple of causes for his downfall.First off, the list of those involved looks too long. In just two-and-a-half months of league football, Dundee fielded  dferent players.Of course, injury and suspension means some of the constant stream of changes were enforced, but others suggest he was never totally sure of what his best line-up was. Given the style of play he wanted, this lack of consistency in selection had to be an issue.Arguably, an even bigger one was that he fell into the rookie manager’s trap of trying to make too many changes too quickly.The Premiership may not be one of the top leagues in Europe but it does have its own unique qualities. One of them, as most new arrivals testy, is the tempo of the play here is more frantic than in many other countries.Even players coming up from England, where the pace is higher than on the continent, usually comment on that.What that means is players from where have to be given time to adjust and, as they do, it’s important they have men around them who are already experienced campaigners in our top ision.A glance down the list of the men used this season suggests there were not enough performers who fitted into that category.Of the  he used, nine were completely new to the league, while eight others had no more than a season’s experience of it.Ironically, the most used who fell into those categories was when  started the solitary win at Hamilton last month but, in the other outings, seven or eight such players were used.That’s not saying these players are not good enough for this level but, as most experienced managers in any league will say, whatever the level of talent, having so many who are not familiar with their surroundings is a risk they wouldn’t be prepared to take.While McCann did bring in vastly-experienced Premiership performer Kenny Miller at the end of the summer transfer window, the loss through injury of Paul McGowan had to be a major blow.And it should not be seen as insignicant that, as he’s scoured the free-agent market since his arrival as manager, new boss Jim McIntyre has paid particular attention to men who know the top flight well.Martin Woods is expected to sign up once he’s proved his fitness, though Celtic on Wednesday may be too early for that. Woods’ old Ross County team-mate from when McIntyre was in charge, Paul Quinn, has also been linked.

title: Council gives backing to referendum on Brexit terms
story: Highland Council has formally backed a second Brexit vote on the terms of the UKsdeparture from the EU.Councillors Deirdre Mackay, Alasdair Christie and John Finlayson submitted the motion calling for "a referendum on the terms of leaving the European Union, with the option of remaining in the European Union".Now that it has passed, the council is obliged to make representations to local MPs and MSPs calling for a "peoplersquos vote."In a contentious debate last week Cllr Deirdre Mackaysaid: "It is important that we donrsquot forget that among the public there really was no reason nor appetite for a referendum on our membership of the European Union."The sole purpose behind the Brexit vote was to uny one political party but the result not only further iding that party but iding and confusing the whole country and instead of clarity we have pandemonium."That led to an angry reaction from some councillors who thought the motion was irrelevant and would not have any impact.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said: "I did say at our pre-meeting that I thought this motion should not have come to this chamber ndash it is not the right place to discuss it."I should also say that I am apolitical completely and I feel this is a political motion, it is not right for this chamber."We talk about localism, we talk about local decisions, and what do we do ndash who have we consulted in this  Nobody, absolutely nobody."And yet we are asking MPs and MSPs to take this forward on behalf of the Highlands. It is wrong."Councillor Mackay said people didnrsquot know what they were voting for ndash what an insult."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Dilapidated factory site to be turned into homes
story: COUNCILLORS have welcomed news that a derelict factory and sawmill which can be seen by people using the new Holm Mills bridge is soon to be demolished.Tulloch Homesrsquo contractors are set to move in on Monday to begin the demolition of the eyesore which was built in  but has stood empty for many years.Tulloch will be taking it down as well as tidying up this area which was most recently used to store equipment while the bridge, part of the West Link, was being built.Inverness West councillor Alex Graham said he was delighted with the news."These are enormous unsightly buildings," he said. "The site is absolutely hideous and itrsquos in your face when you come off the bridge."Itrsquos a long-standing Inverness eyesore and as a resident who frequently uses the West Link, I very much welcome its removal at the earliest possible date."Irsquom sure thatrsquos a sentiment shared by everyone  in the city."Ness-side councillor Alasdair Christie echoed his council colleaguersquos views"Itrsquos in a very prominent site opposite the new roundabout just off the bridge," he said. "The buildings have been hidden from view for so long, but with the new bridge itrsquos a blight on the landscape."Itrsquos been derelict for years and obviously it becomes a danger because it could attract children on to the site. Itrsquos had industrial uses and I understand Tulloch have plans to build houses there."A Tulloch spokesman said the demolition work on the factory and adjacent buildings would be completed by Christmas."In the summer of  we will be preparing for the first phase of homes to be constructed for our Ness Side development, with the first occupants entering their new homes in the autumn," he said."The first phase will comprise a mix of executive and three and four bedroom homes, with access from Dores Road."The development will make a major contribution towards meeting Highland Councilrsquos target to tackle the cityrsquos housing need."Tulloch Homes have approval to build  homes at Ness Side over the next  to  years, after planning consent was granted by Highland Council last December. The spokesman added: "Ness Side will signicantly replenish our land bank in the city to ensure we can meet local demand for some time to come."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Family raise cash for autism centre
story: An Inverness family has raised hundreds of pounds for a local autism support facility.Danielle McLeishrsquos son Connorwas diagnosed with the condition earlier this year.Since then she has been fundraising with the help of her family and friends to raise money for the Pines Centre at Drummond School, which supported little Connor.Miss McLeish and her daughter Christina Rosetook part in the Unicorn Pageant, supported by clothing firm Rogue Attitude.The family also organised a medium night at the Chieftain Hotel.In total they raised pound., and donated the sum to the centre along with a number of items to be raffled off."Drummond have been raising money for playground equipment as well as the library so part of the money will go towards that," Miss McLeish said."We also donated a few items to them as well for a raffle, which will hopefully raise even more."The textile company I work for sent me a load of throw blankets and things like that so they will go into the raffle as well."Pines will get some raffle prizes as well as the cheque."My mum and my brother came along as well. It was great that they were able to come along hey have been a great support for Connor."I donrsquot knowpeople realise the effect autism has on a family as a whole. Itrsquos good for people to be educated, and itrsquos good for us to be able to help in some small way."Now the family are planning to make their fundraising drive an annual event, and they have already had backing from local businesses.Miss McLeish insisted that the whole family are determined to do their bit to support the organisations which continue to support Connor."We have decided to make our fundraiser an annual thing," she added."The Chieftain Hotel have said we can use theirroom whenever we like for our next event which is brilliant."We definitely want to match what wersquove raised this year, andpossible, make it even bigger and better."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Fans shocked by city folk gig walkout
story: Music lovers at an Inverness folk night were left stunned when two people walked out in the middle of a performance.Hamish MacDonald, the first person to be appointed as Scotlandrsquos national scriever, or writer in the Scots language, was performing a song he had penned about US President Donald Trump at Inverness Acoustic and Folk Clubrsquos second meeting.The less-than-complimentary lyrics prompted two American tourists to leave MacGregorrsquos bar in Academy Street, where the performance was taking place.The folk nightrsquos organiser, Jo de Sylva, said: "As is the way in folk music, Hamishrsquos performance did court controversy. He had written a song about Donald Trump, which was very, very funny."It was his third song out of six, and the main act hadnrsquot even come on at that point."Most of the crowd were really enjoying themselves and getting behind Hamish, but this couple just grabbed their jackets and stormed out."It turned out they were American and they had been offended by the song."Itrsquos a shame because folk music is historically about getting people to talk about these things."Miss de Sylva said other members of the audience were left perplexed by the incident, and insisted that type of song is not unusual in folk clubs."Itrsquos exactly the kind of thing you would expect to hear in a folk club. The music is traditionally left-leaning," she said."You need to understand that when you go to a folk club, not everyone there is going to agree with your views."People were a bit taken aback."I waited until the end of the song and tried to go after them but they had already gone."It was very unexpected."Despite the interruption, the rest of the event ran smoothly, and tickets are already selling fast for the clubrsquos next meeting."Apart from that, the night was amazing," Miss de Sylva added."It was exactly what you want a folk night to be like."It was only the second event we had held but it is going so well."There are only six tickets left for the next event, and they have only just gone on sale."Itrsquos gone way beyond what we expected it would be."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Poppyscotlands Inverness centre gives veterans crucial help
story: Thousands of ex-servicemen and women have benefitted from the work of a leading charity in Inverness, according to its first impact report.The five-year report revealed that Poppyscotlandrsquos welfare centre in Strothers Lane has helped more than  people since opening its doors in . Of those enquiries, more than  benefited directly from Poppyscotlandrsquos welfare services, with  receiving specialist support.The most common areas Poppyscotland provided assistance in were financial assistance and support with employment, mental health, housing and benefits.The report also highlighted collaborations between Poppyscotland and other organisations, including Highland Council, NHS Highland and Jobcentre Plus.Centre manager Nina Semple said: "We pride ourselves on taking an evidence-led approach and evaluating outcomes. This report underlines the impact we see our services having every day."While these headline statistics represents a ringing endorsement of our approach, what is most important to us is the le-changing dference our work has on the lives of the iniduals we help."The report coincided with the launch of this yearrsquos Poppy Appeal with a reception at the Town House last Friday.A number of events are planned for the coming weeks as Inverness prepares to mark the centenary of the end of WWI.Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Tennis hub plans get council backing
story: Highland Council has moved a step closer to creating a pound. million regional tennis centre despite some strong opposition.Last Thursday, the care, learning and housing committee voted overwhelmingly in favour of proceeding with an applicationto the next funding round on November .The project is backed by Sport Scotland, Tennis Scotland and the Lawn Tennis Association with proposals that would see funding come from a grant of up to pound million from the Transforming Scottish Indoor Tennis Fund .However, this falls short of the total needed and will leave the council and High Le Highland, the charity which provides leisure services across the region, to source a further half a million pounds.Councillor Andrew Jarvie tabled an amendment opposing the move saying he was "annoyed" because he felt the priority should have been replacing "past it" mobile librariesthat would better serve the whole region.Mr Jarvie said: "I just struggle to connect the dots at a time when we struggle to protect the services that we do have ndash how are we then going on and investing in new services  It seems not the right way to do it."He added the "Inverness-centric project" would be of benefit to the "inner Moray Firth area only."Councillor Richard Laird said he was "a little bit peeved" at the lack of detail.He said: "I donrsquot know whether I support proposals for a tennis centre in Inverness until I have seen the business case, how much it would cost to run and how much it would generate. This proposal is back to front."Despite the objections there was enough support within the committee to push the bid forward to the application stage with a future review to be undertaken on the business case.Brigitte Johnson, whose daughter plays tennis, attended the council in support of the move along with five others.She said: "Currently the issue in Highland is that we donrsquot have any indoor facilities, so kids, adults, anyone who wants to get involved have to travel down the A to Stirling or Gleneagles ndash a long way to go for a game of tennis."Ross Lyon , an S pupil at Fortrose Academy and an avid tennis player believes an indoor facility would greatly benefit young people in the north.He said: "Most tournaments in the winter are indoors down south so having indoor courts up here will allow me to improve and also give me a chance to play all year round which means that I wouldnrsquot fall behind others from the central belt."It would help young kids get into the sport who donrsquot want to play in negative one degrees on a sodden Tuesday night."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Work at Stratton is streets ahead
story: A MAJOR new city housing development has taken a signicant step forward with the completion of an upgraded through route.The pound million Stratton development is expected to provide  new homes for Inverness, including  "affordable" ones.The first householders are expected to move in early next year and developers claim the project will deliver pound. million to the Highland economy along with almost  jobs during the construction phase.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael was due to officially open the new Barn Church Road yesterday.The new road includes improved junctions, pavement and cycleways to accommodate the thousands of residents who will eventually live there.Brian Clarke, from Hazledene Inverness which is leading the construction work on the development, said: "Our investment in Barn Church Road, the key spine infrastructure at Stratton, has been one of the most important aspects underpinning the whole development."Work will now begin on the residential, commercial and community buildings."Our plan includes the creation of green spaces, a childrenrsquos play area, footpaths and cycle paths."The town centre will be an open space with mixed retail and office premises, a health centre, community building and church."The provost said: "The new community at Stratton helps to meet several of the targets that we have for the future of Inverness, offering affordable homes, new jobs and local leisure and health facilities."Highland Council is committed to the creation of new opportunities and sustainable communities which will help retain a young and dynamic workforce in the region."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Young Black Isle pilot keen to see the world
story: SHE may have been fascinated by flying since her childhood, but in the end it did not take Black Isle resident Samantha Fraser long to find her own wings ndash taking just two years from starting her private pilotrsquos licence to being one of Scotlandrsquos youngest female commercial pilots.The -year-old, who was born and brought up in Strathnairn and now lives in Munlochy, said: "My passion is travelling and as part of that going to the airport and watching the aircraft. My first taste at the controls of an aircraft was a flying lesson at Dalcross three years ago and after that, I knew that was what I wanted to pursue as a career."It had run through my mind before, but when I looked at the possibility of becoming a professional pilot initially, I wonderedthis was something I could actually do because it did seem to be so male dominated. But thatrsquos changing rapidly. There are a lot more females training to be pilots now, which is good."Miss Fraser, whose father is Duncan Fraser of Inverness family butcher firm Duncan Fraser and Son, began her path to a flying career by taking three months to qualy as a private pilot, preparing her for the  theoretical exams before advancing onto the flying phase of her course.However, she knew from an early stage whose aircraft she would be flying at the end of her training after quickly being talent spotted by easyJet."All the way through, they were monitoring my training and provided I kept up to their standards, I knew I would be offered a job at the end," Samantha said."From what Irsquove heard so far, itrsquos such a great company to work for and Irsquom really happy to become one of their pilots."With progression to captain usually taking five to seven years, she is well on track to become lead pilot of her own aircraft before she is , but first will be a posting to Edinburgh Airport as a first officer."The routes you fly can y. I think the shortest flight from Edinburgh is over to Belfast. Then the longest is out to Paphos in Cyprus and Tenere, and each of those is just short of five hours each way," she said.Yet even the Cyprus run might be short in comparison to some of her future flightsher ambitions go to plan."At some point, I would like to move on to long haul," she said. "I want to see a bit more of the world."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: Young entrepreneurs to get more support
story: A NEW programme to help young entrepreneurs has been launched in the north.Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas designed IMPACT to uncover a new generation of business talent, with help available from industry experts in order to drive the growth of young peoplersquos businesses.A -month fully-funded business growth programme, it is open to both new and existing entrepreneurs.The project is part of HIErsquos Northern Innovation Hub initiative and is a collaboration with leading consultancy firm Anderson Anderson and Brown .Felix Spittal, senior project manager at HIE, said: "IMPACT is an exciting opportunity for ambitious young entrepreneurs who want to unlock their ideas and encourage positive change and growth."We want the project to annually develop  business leaders of the future from across the Highlands, help them overcome existing challenges, inspire plans, and put in place the foundations of support that will help them thrive."The expertise and experience AAB and their network of collaborators bring to the IMPACT programme is an invaluable resource and will drive the businesses forward."IMPACT is open to anyone under the age of  who is working in a applicant best.Businessman James Robertson, who founded Skye Candles in , has urged young entrepreneurs to make the most of the opportunity."Building a business is not for the faint hearted," he said."Yoursquove got to be passionate about what you do, have a good work ethic and got to be constantly willing to learn and adapt your skills."Making the most of IMPACT will hopefully allow young entrepreneurs to progress their ventures faster, by offering the sort of support that can be invaluable in avoiding costly and time-consuming mistakes."Irsquod definitely encourage young business people from across the Highlands to give it a go and hopefully take their business to the next level."Thursday  Nov  : AM

title: gms we cant take our foot off the gas after sunday its all about hamilton now
story: Gary Mackay-Steven has called on the Dons to follow up their League Cup semi-final success by hitting top form in the Premiership.Aberdeen defeated rivals Rangers - at Hampden in Sunday’s last-four clash to seal ato the national stadium for the final against Celtic on December .That victory has been the highlight of the season so far for the Reds.In the league Derek McInnes’ men have had a patchy start with their haul of  points from nine games leaving them eighth in the Premiership table.Hamilton Accies are the visitors to Pittodrie tonight as the Dons get back to league business.Mackay-Steven believes Aberdeen have yet to reach top form in the league.The winger wants them to start tonight against Accies as they look to capitalise on the confidence-boosting win against the Gers and climb the table.The -year-old said: “We can’t take our foot off the gas and Sunday is gone now – it’s all about Hamilton.“The preparation started on Monday. We enjoyed Sunday but it is gone now and our total focus is on Hamilton.“We can’t take them lightly, we need to be at our bestwe want to start climbing the league.“We feel like we have not hit top gear in the league yet. The league is stronger this year.“We feel teams will be taking points off each other and it’s whoever can get that sustained run of form and sustained run of victories that will really start climbing the league.“We feel more than capable of doing that and it’s time to start showing it in the next few weeks.”Mackay-Steven does not expect an easy evening against Hamilton, who are ninth in the Premiership.He added: “It will be a tough game. They drew with Kilmarnock at the weekend and they are always tough to play against home or away.“We couldn’t celebrate Sunday too much because we’ve had to get back in and focus on Hamilton and trying to get three points.“We need to start climbing the league and hopefully we can use the winning feeling from Sunday over the next few games.”Mackay-Steven thinks Sunday’s win over Rangers can have a big impact on the Aberdeen squad.Seeing off Steven Gerrard’s side has created a feelgood factor around the Dons and Mackay-Steven hopes they can capitalise on that tonight as well as over the next couple of games, away to Kilmarnock on Sunday and at home to Hibs on Friday week.The former Celtic and Dundee United player said: “It was pleasing to go down to Glasgow and beat Rangers down there and get ourselves into a final.“The result can have a massive impact on the squad.“Hopefully it can be a springboard for our league campaign. We’ve got three games coming up in the next nine days.“They are big games coming up but hopefully we can use the confidence and the winning mentality to start picking up our league form.“It’s a big thing . we were confident before the game, but it’s important to get these results to really stamp down what you can do.“The club have been in finals over the last few years and it’s pleasing that we have managed to get into another one by beating Hibs, beating Rangers and St Mirren, all Premiership sides.“It’s been a pleasing run and hopefully we can go a step further and get our name on the trophy.”Prior to Sunday’s game Aberdeen’s ability to win pressure matches against Celtic and Rangers had been questioned.But the victory went some way to answering the critics and Mackay-Steven says the Reds always had belief in themselves. He said: “We never doubted our own ability, although there maybe wasn’t noise coming out of the changing room.“We just focused on what we can handle and what we can do.“We knew we were capable and we went down to Hampden and got the result.“It’s another final and it’s nice to be there but we will look ahead to that when it comes.”

title: dominant dons brush aside hamilton 3 0 at pittodrie
story: Aberdeen continued the feel-good factor of their recent BetFred Cup semi-final win over Rangers by overcoming Hamilton - at Pittodrie.The Dons were - up at half-time courtesy of goals from captain Graeme Shinnie and on loan Manchester United striker James Wilson.Defender Mikey Devlin added to the score-line on the hour mark with a long range effort.Aberdeen made just one enforced change to the side that dumped Rangers - in the BetFred Cup semi-final at Hampden on Sunday.Left-back Andy Considine was an enforced absentee having suffered a neck injury at Hampden.The defender required eight minutes of treatment on the pitch following a head knock and was stretchered off to hospital.Thankfully the injury was not as serious as initially feared and Considine is expected tofor Sunday#s Premiership trip to Kilmarnock.The Dons grabbed the lead in the eighth minute following a period of concerted pressure.Grraeme Shinnie lurked outside the penalty area and was picked out by a corner kick from Niall McGinn.The Dons skipper fired a low  yard drive beyond keeper Gary Woods and into the far corner.Hamilton were denied an equalizer moments later when Aaron McGowan#s powerful drive along the face of goal beat keeper Joe Lewis only to crack off the post.Aberdeen doubled their advantage in the rd minute with a superb strike from on loan Manchester United striker James WILSON.The Old Trafford centre-forward fired a magnicent  yard dipping strike into the far corner.It was a touch of class from Wilson who is at Pittodrie on a season long loan.It was nearly - in the th minute when Scott Wright shimmied past a challenge at the edge of the penalty area before shooting inches over the cross bar.The Reds# dominance continued after the break when Wright broke through on goal, weaving through two challenges.However his  yard drive was saved by the ing Woods.On the hour mark it was - when Mikey DEVLIN fired in a  yard shot from  the right that keeper Woods got a touch to it..He should have kept it out but the ball went over the line as the Reds threatened to run riot.Moments later Shay Logan unleashed a superb  yard drive only to be denied a stunning goal by a ing save from Woods.Hamilton#s night got even worse in injury time when Dougie Imrie was sent off in injury time for a second yellow following a foul on Shinnie.ABERDEEN: Lewis, Logan, Lowe, Devlin, McKenna, Shinnie, Ferguson, McGinn, Mackay-Steven, Wright, Wilson.Subs: May , McLennan , Anderson Subs not used:  Cerny,  Ball,  Gleeson, Cosgrove.HAMILTON: Woods, McGowan, McMann, Gordon, Tshiembe, Kilgallon, Imrie, Bingham, Miller, Martin, Brustad.Subs: Keatings , Penny ,  Smith Subs not used: Marsden,  Want, Kelly,  Sowah.Referee: Greig Aitken.Attendance: ,

title: burst water main on aberdeen road1
story: A burst water main has caused flooding in an Aberdeen community.The fault is with a pipe on Cardens Knowe in Bridge of Don but it has left nearby Scotstown Road submerged in water. vw, px"  Scottish Water is currently investigating the incident.In a post on their website, Scottish Water said: #A burst water main has been located on Cardens Knowe causing no water, low pressure and discoloured water to the surrounding area.#We have a squad on site and hope to have the repairs complete as quickly as possible.#At the moment we anticipate this fault to be repaired by .pm.#Apologies for the inconvenience caused this evening.#A spokesman said: #Scottish Water received reports of water rising in the area this evening and an operative is on site to investigate.#We apologise for any inconvenience as these investigations are carried out and thank customers and motorists for their patience.#

title: calls for major north east roads to be linked during a96 dualling project
story: Councillors have said every effort should be made to link two north-east roads during a dualling project.Members of the Formartine area committee were asked to provide their views on nine options being considered for the A dual carriageway proposals by Transport Scotland.Various routes are being looked at between Huntly and Inverurie with councillors urging for new link roads between the A and the A.Transport Scotland is hoping to have the fullof the A upgraded to a dual carriageway by .Three route sections have been brought forward with each containing three distinct options.Two of the routes have suggested bypassing Inverurie from the north, with the third looking to bypass the town from the south.Councillors said they would prefer Inverurie was bypassed from the north when considering the options.However, members of the committee expressed their disappointment that another initial option, named Option Q, was not being taken forward.The option would have linked with the A at Dyce.Councillor Anne Stirling said: “I think this is a missed opportunity for Transport Scotland. We only get one chance at this and I would like to have seen every effort made for the A to be linked with the route.“This might be using existing roads or even a new link road. We should be really pushing for this to be part of the dualling project for the A.“I also think we should be making sure that public transport and links are considered at a very early stage.”Councillor Richard Thomson added: “It will be great to see the infrastructure being upgraded and up to a standard that the north-east really deserves and probably should have had around  years ago.“Looking at the options, my preference would be to see Inverurie bypassed for the north as this would provide more opportunities.”Director of infrastructure services at the local authority, Stephen Archer, said in a report: “Council officers are of the view thatoptions to the north-east of Inverurie were taken forward, this would likely provide an attractive route into Aberdeen for existing users of the A.”

title: draculas 100 year old recipe resurrected for halloween
story: A -year-old north-east recipe from the we of Dracula’s creator has been resurrected just in time for Halloween.Bram Stoker’s we Florence penned the instructions for “Dracula Salad” and they were published in a pamphlet to raise money to renovate Cruden Parish Church.The dish, one of two submitted by Florence for the pamphlet, is perfect for vegetarian vampires –there is such a thing.It instructs the cook to “arrange alternate slices of ripe tomatoes, and ripe, purple, egg-shaped plums in a dish and dress with oil and vinegar French dressing”.The second recipe is a savoury dish made from plums rolled in bacon, fried, and served on an oval crouton.These dishes have now received a new lease of le after being published as part of a new book, When Brave Men Shudder: The Scottish Origins of Dracula, by Mike Shepherd.The book tells the story of Bram Stoker’s many visits to Cruden Bay on the north-east coast of Scotland and how Slains Castle famously became the inspiration for Count Dracula’s Transylvanian lair.From , Bram took monthly holidays in the Aberdeenshire fishing village of Port Erroll – now called Cruden Bay – where he wrote his books.He first discovered the village while on a walking holiday along the Aberdeenshire coast.Speaking of the experience, he wrote: “When first I saw the place I fell in love with it.”Bram Stoker died in , the same year his we Florence submitted her recipes for the pamphlet entitled Cruden Recipes and Wrinkles.The author discovered the pamphlet at his neighbour’s home and said it was a touching tribute to Florence’s late husband.Mr Shepherd said: “The recipe book belongs to one of my neighbours and I was astonished when she showed it to me.“The pamphlet went on sale only a few months after Bram Stoker’s death in , and the recipe stands as Florence Stoker’s memorial to him. It honours the long-standing association between Bram Stoker, Cruden Bay and his most famous book.”

title: knitters poppy call up draws 7500 donations
story: A north-east community group has knitted more than , Remembrance poppies.In May the group of churchgoers from Westhill said they hoped to produce , poppies, which would mark the - war, in time for Remembrance Day.Since then, almost , poppies have been sent to the group from across the UK – including Glasgow, Edinburgh and parts of England – and creations were even sent from as far away as Australia to be part of the project.Project co-ordinator Aileen Reid said a previous story in The Evening Express had helped boost the cause.She added: “We simply didn’t realise how many people read the Evening Express online and guess from some of their emails that they are ex-pats living away from home and using the EE to keep in touch with their roots.“As well as the fantastic effort by local knitters across Aberdeenshire, we have received poppies from Glasgow, Edinburgh, and both the north and south of England.“We are really touched by this kindness and by the time taken by lots of people to contribute to the project.“We have now received almost , poppies and are looking forward to displaying them all during Remembrance week.”The poppies will be on display at several places across Westhill, including Trinity and Skene churches where the original knitters attend, as well as Westhill Library, the Village Store in Skene, the Hampton by Hilton Westhill and local charity SensationALL – which offers services to people with multiple support needs and their families.Reverend Stella Campbell, who oversees Westhill and Skene Church, said: “What started as a small, church-based project has grown way beyond our expectations.“It has encouraged lots of groups of people to come together, knitting or crocheting poppies, and often sharing memories from their childhood and younger years.“We have knitters in their s and children from Skene Primary School joining in.”She added: “It has created a great sense of community as well as benefiting the Poppy Scotland appeal, with a small donation from each poppy bag going to the charity.“We all now hope that young and old alike will plan walks and visits to see the poppies between November  and  throughout Westhill and Skene.“I’d like to thank The Evening Express for printing this story and helping us to bring our community together in this way.”

title: new flights to benefit offshore workers
story: An airline is to introduce a new morning flight from Durham to Aberdeen.Eastern Airways, a franchise partner of Flybe, has added the flight from Durham Tees Valley Airport.From November , the first flight of the day to Aberdeen will leave Durham Tees Valley at .am, arriving at .am, from Monday to Thursday.The airline will also be adding in a Friday departure from Durham Tees Valley to .pm, arriving in Aberdeen at .pm.Eastern Airways schedule will include up to  flights a week between Durham Tees Valley and Aberdeen.Roger Hage, Eastern Airways’ general manager operations, said: “Having listened to passenger feedback, we have improved the first departure of the day to an earlier .am departure to north-east Scotland, which helps particularly those connecting offshore.“Given many of our customers are heading with either Bristow Helicopter operated transfers or on our own integrated service to Shetland, their feedback is imperative to supporting the many who have flown with us now since .“This change and the re-timed Friday departure will also help to improve the route’s on-time performance.”

title: thousands apply for cash after benefits delay
story: Around , people in the north-east have been forced to apply for emergency cash because of a delay in their benefits, new figures show.The figures show that one-third of the , awarded the grants applied to the Scottish Welfare Fund for a crisis grant due to their benefits being delayed between April  and June  this year.The fund provides applicants with a cash injection, aimed at relieving immediate pressure.Money will typically be enough to pay for short-term food or heating costs, with the average payout in Aberdeen being £.This is the first time the Scottish Welfare Fund has published the number of applications due to benefits delays.More than , people in the area have been awarded the grants, prompting a payout from the council totalling £, in the second quarter of the year.The findings coincide with the rollout of Universal Credit in the north-east, to be completed today.Controversy has swirled around Universal Credit, with some claimants being forced to wait up to five weeks for their first payment.The system was intended to streamline the benefits system, amalgamating six dferent means-tested benefits, including jobseeker’s allowance.North-east MSP Lewis Macdonald said: “These numbers are dramatic, and they demonstrate the hit that people have taken.“Having received benefits in the past, they are now faced with a gap in their income because of the introduction of Universal Credit.“We heard in the budget earlier this week the Chancellor proposes to put more money into Universal Credit, but for , people in Aberdeen that’s too little, too late.”A spokeswoman for the Department of Work and Pensions said: “Universal Credit simplies an out-of-date, complex system that often trapped people in unemployment.”
